Headline: Barron's(7/9) Streetwise: Absolutely, Positively No One's Safe
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   It's the story of so many upwardly mobile consumers. Private-equity pros began the current buyout cycle like thrift-store regulars, flaunting the bargains they'd found among others' castoffs. Now they're beginning to become more label-conscious, paying up for quality, timelessness and prestige.   Partly because of the presumed ready bid from LBO firms, a lot of lower-quality companies have had their stocks buoyed by deal premiums. This has narrowed the divide betweenbetter and worse businesses, reducing the number of true-value opportunities in the market.   And so in the past several months, well-run, dearly loved, honest-to-goodness growth companies have come in for leveraged-buyout treatment. Witness First Data (ticker: FDC), Alltel (AT), Harrah's Entertainment (HET) and, just last week, Hilton Hotels (HLT).   This, among other factors, hints at the advancing maturation of the buyout cycle. But it also implies that big-growth companies are where relative value lies.   This brings us to Fedex (FDX), one of the greatest of American brands and a business that, believe it or not, could in theory lure a private buyer at 20% or more above its current $110 share price.   Too big, you say? Not these days. Fedex's $35 billion enterprise value ($34 billion market capitalization and $1 billion of net debt) puts it in the zone of larger deals favored by cash-sodden LBO firms. Too cyclical? Not really, given its fairly steady-growth record and increasing exposure to the more-stable ground- and freight-transport businesses. Too tough to finance in a skittish debt market? Probably not, given all the real assets that can secure borrowings, in the form of nearly 700 aircraft and 44,000 trucks.   Fedex's enterprise value is now less than seven-times earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization for the fiscal year that ended in May, and around six-times expected fiscal 2008 Ebitda. One need not get anywhere near the recent double-digit Ebitda valuations of LBOs in other industries to get to a share price more than 20% above current levels.   Bulls on the stock, mindful of the LBO math, point out that 70% of Fedex's $3.5 billion in planned capital spending this year is aimed at expansion rather than needed maintenance. That flexibility provides a cushion that could embolden private-equity buyers and comfort lenders. And the notion that Fedex Kinko's ailing retail unit could be turned around might draw the kind of private-equity folks who never saw a poor business they didn't think they could revive.   None of this suggests that a deal is imminent or even likely. And, for certain, Fedex founder, Chairman and CEO Fred Smith has given no public indication that he would be amenable to going private.   But the numbers laid out above are no secret to investment bankers, and in this environment not many companies can be considered off-limits to private money.   Even without a deal, Fedex shares could do just fine. The stock is more than 8% off its February high, as fears of an economic slowdown have dampened investor enthusiasm and the company missed fourth-quarter profit forecasts.   The shares, though, are reasonably priced at around 15 times expected fiscal 2008 earnings. The company's steadier ground and freight businesses have increased revenue 35% over the past two years, faster than the company's 20% pace, which over time should help Fedex narrow its valuation gap with United Parcel Service (UPS) -- which, please note, faces another possible strike in a year.   It never pays to draw broad conclusions from a low-volume, holiday-interrupted summer week. Even more hazardous is reading much into the final hours of such a week.   Still, stocks were presented with a couple of handy excuses to pull back during the 3 1/2 trading days last week, and refused to do so. The 10-year Treasury yield backed up from 5.03% to 5.19%, an area that had spooked equity traders weeks earlier. And crude oil ran above $76 a barrel.   The Dow chart for Friday shows it touched an afternoon low at 12:25 p.m., almost exactly the time a press release hit the tape to announce that KKR had closed its LBO of Dollar General, a sign that the debt market absorbed one of its more at-risk financings.   Without inferring too much, the market continues to earn the benefit of the doubt even if range-bound right now.   Also encouraging for bulls: The public isn't buying stocks and corporate insiders have nearly quit selling. Net flows into stock mutual funds were again anemic last week. And the ratio of dollar-weighted insider selling to buying was eight, down from 11 a week earlier and 19 a year ago. The last time selling was so light for two weeks straight was before stocks began a little run higher in early April.   ---   E-mail: michael.santoli(@)barrons.com   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) Quarterly Review: An Unexpected Windfall
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jack Willoughby   Although many investors doubted them, the bulls proved they were strong enough to lift the market in the second quarter -- even if their muscles betrayed a little stress at the end. The average U.S. diversified equity fund advanced 6.17% in the latest three-month period, in line with the S&P 500's 6.28% return, and almost three times better than the first quarter's return of 2.31%, according to Lipper, Reuters' investment-tracking unit. As impressive as that was, foreign funds did much better.   What happened? Wasn't the U.S. economy supposed to slow, dragging down earnings growth and global stock prices?   It did slow, but not as much as expected. Strong advances in energy and other commodity prices, related gains at oil-services operators, the ongoing rise of global construction companies and improved foreign economies helped offset weakness in areas like housing and finance. Shares of companies such as Foster Wheeler (ticker: FWLT), Schlumberger (SLB), McDermott International (MDR) and Honeywell (HON) surged. Many of these same trends powered overseas returns.   What's more, a handful of Internet, telecom and tech plays also contributed, raising the possibility that they may become even more important if U.S. growth downshifts further. Momentum investors scooped up former favorites such as Amazon.com (AMZN), Nokia (NOK), Corning (GLW) and even pricey Google (GOOG).   One of the quarter's bigger surprises was the performance of the fund most identified with large-cap growth: Fidelity's Magellan (FMAGX). The now shrunken Goliath, under Harry Lange, produced a second-quarter return of 8.60%, the best among Fidelity's jumbos. Is large-cap investing back?   These unexpected second-quarter pleasures shouldn't distract investors from the fact that the market is starting to distinguish between companies with real-growth potential and those riding the crest of an economic cycle. In theory, at least, slower growth should at last favor large-cap stocks (though mid- and small-caps still prevailed in the second quarter) that have more ways to capture growth and greater resources to sustain it than smaller entities do.   Among those benefitting from gains in oil services and telecom was Robert Hagstrom, portfolio manager of the Legg Mason Growth Trust (LMGTX), the top performer (up 12.55%) in the large-cap growth category. Foster Wheeler's construction-driven 83% quarterly rise and Nokia's 23% gain prompted by the worldwide wireless boom contributed to his gains.   Hagstrom expects some of his bigger Internet bets like Yahoo! (YHOO) to begin to pay off shortly along with other underperforming large-caps like General Electric (GE) and AIG (AIG), which are now growing faster than the underlying market. These giants, he says, are flat-out cheap. "We haven't seen multiples this low in the mega-cap area since the early 1990s."   For Warren Spitz, senior portfolio manager of RiverSource Diversified Equity Income fund (INDZX), whose 9.12% second-quarter return made it the top performer in its category, the trick was overweighting the right sectors like energy/oil services and producer durables and picking the strongest stocks in the weaker sectors. McDermott and Caterpillar (CAT) performed well in strong sectors, but re-insurer XL Capital (XL) was a huge help -- up 20% in the financial category, which was flat.   One of the early-year miscalculations was the direction of commodity prices: They didn't continue to fall, notes Jerry Jordan, portfolio manager for the Jordan Opportunity fund (JORDX). Forecasts have to be "adjusted up," says Jordan, whose 13.12% return was tops among multi-cap core funds.   Fear of hedge-fund blowups -- real and imagined -- are going to further compress the multiples of big brokerage houses like Goldman Sachs (GS), Merrill Lynch (MER) and Morgan Stanley (MS), says Jordan, who views this as an excellent-buying opportunity.   Commodity prices weren't the only thing that forecasters got wrong. Many analysts and traders overestimated how severely an economic slowdown would affect U.S. manufacturers, particularly big ones with sizable foreign operations. Mostly because of the dollar's continued problems and the strength of many overseas economies, world equity funds, up 8.30% on average, fared better than U.S. domestic funds' 6.17% gain.   Not every country kicked in equally. Emerging-market funds produced an average return of 14.33%. But 63 China region funds on average rose 21.53% while the typical Japanese fund rose a measly 0.09% in the quarter.   The future may belong to large-cap funds, but the present and recent past remain solidly in the hands of funds focused on smaller stocks. Large-cap growth funds returned 6.42% in the quarter, outpacing large-cap value vehicles' 6.25% and marking their strongest quarterly gain since 2004. But mid-cap and small-cap growth funds returned 8.13% and 7.49%, respectively.   Among sectors, natural-resource funds -- powered by the snapback in many commodity prices -- provided the strongest gain, 14.67%, on average. Tech and telecom specialists were close behind with respective gains of 9.02% and 11.14%. In contrast, real-estate funds slid 7.96%, leaving them down an average 4.71% for the year.   Strong markets made for great stock-picking by the second-quarter's stars. Lipper's Mid-Cap Core quarterly champ American Century's Veedot Investments (AMVIX) uses a model that's constantly searching for accelerating growth; the portfolio can turn over two or three times in a year as it fine-tunes these holdings. Among the quarter's winners: DryShips (DRYS), up 93%, and IntercontinentalExchange (ICE), up 21%.   David Hollond, co-portfolio manager of the mid-cap growth category winner Heritage Giftrust (TWGTX), gained by 15.06%. His holding of BE Aerospace (BEAV) which makes plane interiors, was a late-cycle play that has turned into a winner, rising 30% in the quarter. The company benefitted from international carriers looking to retrofit old planes as well as new orders for wide-body plane fittings. Another favorite, Gamestop (GME), a video-games retailer that should profit from exploding demand from newcomers (including women and middle-aged players), a general console upgrade and new-store openings. It rose 20%.   Even some funds that limit their choices strutted their stuff in the quarter. Lipper's small-cap growth winner was Winslow Green Growth Fund (WGGFX), up 19.43% thanks to strong performances by digital-marketer aQuantive (AQNT). Its shares jumped 129% in the quarter: It agreed to sell itself to Microsoft. Winslow Green also bet on Fuel Tech (FTEK), which helps utilities burn coal more cleanly (up 39%), and SurModics (SRDX), a drug delivery company (up 39%).   Absent from the Winslow Green holdings are popular corn-ethanol names. Says Jack Robinson, portfolio manager: "We've avoided corn. We don't believe ethanol's all that economical."   More limited still is tiny Bullfinch Greater Western New York (BWNYX), with assets of $700,000, that won top honors in the Multi-Cap category, with an 11.4% return thanks to Corning, which rose 12%, Bausch & Lomb (BOL), up 36%, and Graham (GHM), a builder of oil-service equipment that jumped 71%.   "Our tight regional specialization actually helps to focus our analysis," says portfolio manager Chris Carosa. "We spend a lot of time on a few companies and therefore are better able to buy when the shares are out of favor."   And sell, of course, when they're in favor.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Chile Collahuasi Copper Workers To Strike Monday -Union
Story: SANTIAGO (Dow Jones)-At rallies held throughout the day, unionized workers at Chilean copper mine Dona Ines de Collahuasi rejected the company's latest contract proposal for a 4% wage hike and will go on strike at the start of the first shift Monday morning, a union leader said Saturday afternoon.   According to union president Hernan Farias, workers at rallies at the mine site and in the city of Iquique were all in favor of walking off the job Monday. Government mediated negotiations ended Friday evening with mine management proposing a 4% wage hike, "but they withdrew several bonuses that had been offered earlier in the week," he added.   Another union leader, Cristian Arancibia, who was present during negotiations, explained that although the company proposed a 4% hike Friday, their formal offer still stands at a 3.2% wage hike.   "Since they didn't formally make a new offer, only a proposal, we weren't legally bound to hold another strike vote and the company can now replace striking workers as of Monday," Arancibia said.   The 698-strong union had already voted in favor of the strike a week ago.   According to local labor laws, another government mediated, five-day period can be sought to avert the strike, but both parties must agree to the mediation. The union ruled out it will seek this mediation, according to the union leaders.   "If we weren't able to reach an agreement in the 45 days the law allows, another five days aren't going to help us," Arancibia said.   Collahuasi is a joint venture between Xstrata PLC (XTA.LN) and Anglo American PLC (AAUK), each with a 44% stake. The remaining 12% is held by a Japanese consortium headed by Mitsui & Co. (MITSY).   The workers are seeking an 8% wage increase, improved education and housing benefits, production bonuses and a 12 million peso ($22,918) copper price bonus, in light of booming copper prices in 2005 and 2006. They also seek improved health benefits as the mine is located at 4,500 meters above sea level.     -By Carolina Pica, Dow Jones Newswires; 56-2-460-8544; carolina.pica@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 13:43 ET (17:43 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Venezuela Natl Guard Takes Over Paralyzed Oil Rigs -Report
Story: CARACAS (Dow Jones)--Venezuela's national guard took control of four oil rigs paralyzed by oil workers' protests in the northwestern state of Zulia, near lake Maracaibo, a local newspaper reported Saturday.   Rafael Zambrano, president of the Fedepetrol oil workers union, told El Nacional newspaper that these oil rig operations, including equipment, would come under military control. Military officials will be responsible for safeguarding the equipment, the paper reported.   Officials for state-owned Petroleos de Venezuela, or PdVSA, could not immediately be reached for comment.   "These are activities traditionally performed by specialized private sector companies," Zambrano was quoted as saying. He also expressed concern that people who know little about the business would take over oil operations.   Oil workers protested in recent days as they negotiate with the government over a new labor contract for 2007-2009, the paper reported.   As part of his nationalization drive President Hugo Chavez recently took majority control over four heavy-crude upgrading projects along the Orinoco River belt, and his government is also set to seize a series of rigs in various oil fields.     -Raul Gallegos, Dow Jones Newswires, 58-212-564-1449; raul.gallegos@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 07:39 ET (11:39 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) Follow-Up: A Golden Name Gets Golden Price
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   It was a busy fortnight for the Hiltons. Paris was sprung from the slammer to bask in the coddling spotlight of Larry King Live. Then, the hotel chain that's her family business announced its own liberation -- this one from the public market -- courtesy of $26 billion to be supplied by the Blackstone Group (ticker: BX).   The all-cash offer, unveiled fittingly just before Independence Day, values Hilton (HLT) at 47.50 -- 40% above its July 2 close. (The stock and related call options ran up July 3, before the announcement.) The price also is 66% higher than what Hilton was fetching 14 months ago, when Barron's highlighted hotels in general and Hilton in particular ("Golden Name, Platinum Properties," May 15, 2006).   The agreement is a big vote of confidence in the longevity of the current hotel boom. It also made instant targets of other big hotel brands and spurred heavy trading of their shares.   For Blackstone, which has invested some $15 billion in hotel assets over the past three years and now controls more than 100,000 rooms, the buyout snags an instantly recognizable brand and a keystone for its hospitality-property portfolio.   With more than 2,800 hotels and 485,000 rooms in some 80 countries, Hilton also gives Blackstone a quicker check-in to the fast-growing overseas lodging market.   As such, the New York private-equity firm probably won't strip and flip Hilton assets the way it did with parts of Equity Office Properties after it bought out that company for $39 billion earlier this year. Sure, some property sales are to be expected, but "look for Blackstone to start investing in everything from rejuvenation at the property level to expansion on a global scale," predicts Peter Slatin, editor of the online real-estate newsletter, the Slatin Report.   While newly public Blackstone hasn't said how it will finance the deal, it could scour Hilton's balance sheet for ways to securitize the franchise -- structuring, for instance, real-estate investment trusts from hotel-owned properties or fashioning master limited partnerships from long-term management contracts.   The transaction, subject to shareholder approval, is expected to close in the fourth quarter. "Given the competitive bidding for Equity Office Properties and the amount of capital chasing large real-estate portfolios, we cannot rule out other bids," notes Raymond James analyst William Crow. But at about 45.50, the shares were trading at a 4% discount to the bid -- apparently reflecting lingering debt-market nervousness, and the view that the premium is ample enough to discourage other suitors.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) Up & Down Wall Street: Truly Al-ARM-ing
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Alan Abelson   Forget about global warming, weapons of mass destruction, private equity and other dire threats to the survival of this small planet and the pullulating billions that people it. Concentrate, instead, on a much more deadly menace: the spreading contagion of dynastic rule.   Ever since Cro-Magnon strode around what's now France, mankind has always treasured kin and clan. But here we are, some half a million years later, and the human race, which has attained such heightsof cognitive achievement as to devise the iPhone, remains politically stuck in the Paleolithic Age, where blood ties are trump.   Understand, we're all for spousal harmony and being kind to your kids and dogs, but why in the world is it necessary, just because you're, say, president, for one of your immediate family to become president, too?   That sort of genetic claim on power is only to be expected in backward nations that still regard kings and queens with serious reverence or tin-pot dictatorships or Stepford nations like North Korea, where the deceased father of the current ruler remains president for eternity (or until that happy day when the country implodes). But a dynastic democracy? Strictly an oxymoron.   Yet here's Cristina Kirchner, the wife of Argentina's president, Nestor Kirchner, being primed to succeed him come next October's election. Yes, we're aware the Kirchners are the leading lights of the Peronista party, founded by the late and unlamented (at least by most decent folk) Juan Peron, and that Juan's third wife, Isabel, succeeded him as president. But she got the heave-ho by the army after a little over a year and, presumably, in today's Argentina the Perons and all they stood for are not so much sacred tradition as ancient history.   We prefer to think that the passing-of-the-baton routine of the Kirchners is something else the Clintons have to answer for. Except for Hillary setting such a prominent example, one wonders if the Nestor-to-Cristina ploy would even have been tried, much less, as seems likely, succeeded. In the same vein, would the Tweedledee and Tweedledum identical twins who serve as Poland's president and prime minister have attained such eminence had it not been for the succession with only eight years in between Daddy Bush and Dubya's presidencies? We can only say thank heavens Laura Bush has no interest in the job.   What got us ruminating on such a frivolous subject as politics was last week's neat cover piece by our Washington editor, Jim McTague, that rated the various and sundry candidates according to their record and likely impact on those things that matter most -- taxes, investment, health care and energy. While Jim mightily enhanced our knowledge of the candidates' positions, we must confess our personal preference remained unchanged: We still stand four-square for Mr. (or Ms.) None of the Above.     After modest reflection, any disinterested observer can't help but find that accompanying table quite alARMing. (See accompanying illustration -- Barron's July 9, 2007) It's from a recent MacroMavens report, the handiwork of the incomparable Stephanie Pomboy, whose rants and raves we've had the pleasure of occasionally sharing with you. What its blood-curdling numbers depict is that the woes of mortgage lenders are not, as so widely believed, confined to the beleaguered subprime contingent, but are casting a much larger and chillier shadow.   More specifically, the table shows all too clearly that an astounding percentage of adjustable-rate mortgages already are underwater, and it estimates how much equity would be wiped out if home values decline by 5%, 10% and 15% and translates the corresponding losses into dollars.   As Stephanie comments: "Based on the share of ARMs in some state of negative equity at the end of last year and the decline in home prices so far in 2007, a stunning $693 billion in mortgage loans are already in the red. Assuming lenders are able to recover 70% of those assets -- which seems optimistic given the massive amount of housing inventory yet to be unwound -- that means mortgage lenders are already grappling with $210 billion in outright losses."   And that, she points out, is merely the direct hit. Thanks to what she nicely dubs the "divine miracle of leverage," the total financial exposure to these claims is many multiples of that. To which we say, ugh!   What's more, Stephanie notes, these horrendous losses are coming at a time when the financial sector is "uniquely unprepared to withstand them." Commercial banks, she points out, have let their loan-loss provisions sink to 20-year lows while increasing their exposure to real estate to record highs. Mortgages, she reckons, account for a tidy 55% of total bank loans -- and that doesn't include the trillion dollars worth of mortgage-backed securities on bank balance sheets.   So much for the myth that banks have cleverly "offloaded" their real-estate risk.     Back in may of 2005, contributing editor Rhonda Brammer wrote a skeptical story on a smallish over-the-counter number called Mannatech. The company had gone public in the frothy markets of the late '90s and operated, as Rhonda put it, in a "backwater" of the health-care industry. Its IPO came at $8 a share and, in the fashion of those days, hit $44.50 before the session called it quits. The stock went pretty much downhill after that, sinking to less than $1 in the big bear market of the early part of this decade.   When Rhonda caught up with the company, the shares had recovered to around 20 and earnings were rising briskly. Texas-based Mannatech, then as now, was in the business of peddling nutritional supplements called glyconutrients abroad as well as in the good old USA. Since it outsourced all its manufacuturing and conspicuously lacked any high-tech breakthrough, its rapid growth was, essentially, Rhonda explained, the product of a very successful hard-sell marketing scheme.   Specifically, the company created a multilevel marketing setup to push its line of supplements. Its sales people, dubbed "associates," earn money not only by selling the supplements, but by recruiting other associates who seek to recruit still more sales people. A not unfamiliar daisy chain. What made the approach especially effective and efficient was its liberal use of the Internet.   Rhonda duly noted that co-founder Same Caster had tried his hand at previous ventures without much to show for it until he came up with Mannatech. As it happens, as she also noted, those earlier ventures yielded some unwelcome side effects in the form of run-ins with the Texas Attorney General that required one company to sharply tone down its promotional claims, and another to ditch its main product, which the AG alleged was a "hoax."   In the course of her research, Rhonda also discovered that Mannatech had indulged in dubious claims for its supplements as a cure for a variety of diseases from cancer to hepatitis. Mannatech blamed errant associates for suggesting its glyconutrients were of use as medical treatment and it cited a pertinent disclaimer on its Website, printed, as Rhonda related, in small type after pages and pages of testimonials to their positive effects on virtually every disease known to suffering man.   In reaction to Rhonda's piece, Mannatech shares plunged from 20 to 12. Prompting this brief revisit was that the stock took another header last Friday on news that the Texas attorney general was on the company's case again, filing suit against it in Travis County district court, co-founder Caster and other key officials, claiming they concocted "an elaborate scheme to defraud innocent consumers across the nation" and alleging illegal sales and marketing practices that claimed its supplements are effective in treating such diseases as autism and Down's syndrome as well as cancer etc.   In short, for Mannatech it was the same old story, the story that Rhonda and Barron's broke over two years ago. The company, incidentally, on Friday acknowledged the suit with this resounding declaration: "We are aware of the situation and will be taking appropriate action to address any issue or concerns from the Texas attorney general's office. We take matters of this nature very seriously and intend to cooperate to reach a resolution."   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: France CDC's De Romanet: In Favor Of 'Economic Patriotism'
Story: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France (Dow Jones)--Augustin de Romanet, the head of Caisse des Depots et Consignations, said Saturday he is in favor of "economic patriotism," reiterating a stance he's taken to help the government solve potential ownership problems in key French companies.   "Economic patriotism means making a French company prosperous in France on French soil," De Romanet told reporters in Aix-en-Provence. "There's an economic patriotism in the U.S., in China, in Hungary. We have a duty to be patriots, too."   De Romanet, who took the reins of the state-owned investment bankin March, may help President Nicolas Sarkozy to find a way out of ownership problems that afflict companies such as European Aeronautic Defense and Space Co. (5730.FR), in which CDC has already bought a 2.25% stake.   The French and German governments have been in dispute over how to keep a balanced share of interests over EADS. Sarkozy and German Chancellor Angela Merkel are due to meet in Toulouse later this month to discuss in detail the balance of power within the Franco-German company.   Economic patriotism, a stance governments take to prevent companies from being sold to foreign investors, is a high priority in France, where several CAC40 companies, such as Danone SA (GDNNY), are vulnerable to potential bids from foreign competitors and are often rumored to be a potential target.     -By Gabriele Parussini, Dow Jones Newswires; gabriele.parussini@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 07:25 ET (11:25 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) Commodities Corner: A Sweet Move For Sugar
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Susan Buchanan   As corn-syrup prices surge, some U.S. makers of soft drinks are going back to basics -- to pure sugar. Soda and food companies switched to high-fructose corn syrup starting in the late 1970s, and especially after sugar prices rocketed in 1980. But manufacturers are taking a fresh look at sugar now that prices have dropped in the U.S. from last year's hurricane-related peak, while corn-syrup costs are rising as corn is needed for ethanol.   HFCS 55, used in soft drinksand made of 55% fructose and 45% glucose, or corn syrup, was quoted at 18.9 cents a pound Friday in the Midwest, and more than 20 cents a pound in the Northeast. Midwest beet sugar sold at 25 cents a pound Friday, while refined cane sugar in the Northeast was 27.5 cents.   Big soft-drink makers are testing cane sugar in products, and fast-growing Jones Soda (ticker:JSDA) made the switch to sugar in March. Seattle-based Jones converted all of the 17 U.S. plants it uses from HFCS, after learning customers wanted a sugar-based product. Peter van Stolk, Jones' founder and CEO, says earnings took a hit because of conversion costs, but the move was worth it over the long haul. Jones is about to launch a pure-cane cola, which he says has "a distinct flavor compared with other colas. Real sugar has a very different taste from HFCS."   Stolk adds that "if one of the larger cola companies wanted to switch to real sugar, the taste of their product would change significantly."   John Sicher, editor of Beverage Digest, says big soft-drink makers have loyal customers and don't like to mess with ingredients or sweeteners, "but we've seen some line extensions" to brands. For example, PepsiCo (PEP) might test market a drink called Pepsi Natural made from cane sugar in late 2007 or early 2008, and Cadbury-Schweppes (CSG) has already tested Dr. Pepper with cane sugar in the Midwest, he says. Mexican-made Coca-Cola (KO) with cane is selling well in the U.S. Southwest, analysts say. Spokesmen for Pepsi and Coke wouldn't comment last week on their beverage-ingredient plans.   Other cane-based sodas include Jolt Cola, made by Wet Planet Beverages; several brands sold in health-food stores, and imports. Sports drinks Gatorade and PowerAde use a sugar-HFCS blend, but newer energy drinks, like Red Bull and Rock Star, are mainly sweetened with sugar.   Ron Sterk, assistant editor at Milling & Baking News, points to barriers to switching to sugar, saying formulas must be adjusted since HFCS is only 99% as sweet as sugar. More liquid sugar would have to be produced in the U.S., because ice cream gobbles up much of what's available now. And companies making the change would have to get out of HFCS contracts, which are mostly annual.   Craig Ruffolo, vice president at McKeany-Flavell, sweetener-ingredient marketers in California, says "traditionally, HFCS has cost less than sugar in the U.S. and still does. But companies are in research and development, and might cross over if the difference in prices makes it economically viable." With tens of millions of corn acres, the U.S. is the lowest-cost HFCS producer, he says. But sugar tends to be cheaper in European and other nations where beets or cane are grown and corn isn't as widely cultivated.   ---   SUSAN BUCHANAN is a senior soft-commodities reporter for Dow Jones Newswires in New Orleans.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Motorola, Nokia: Phone Batteries That Exploded Were Fakes
Story: BEIJING (AP)--Mobile phone batteries that exploded in flames during tests by officials in southern China were counterfeit, spokeswomen for Nokia Corp. (NOK) and Motorola Inc. (MOT) said Saturday.   The Guangdong Industrial and Commercial Administration said on its Web site that four batteries exploded while being recharged during quality tests. Forty percent of phone batteries and 80% of chargers failed the tests.   The tests also found that of 40 locally purchased batteries, 15 had a smaller capacity that labeled, sometimes by as much as half.   Motorola spokeswoman Mary Lamb told The Associated Press that Motorola immediately sent a team to Guangdong province and found that the tests were legitimate, but that the three batteries labeled Motorola were counterfeit.   "We went with members of the lab and actually looked at batteries and determined they were not authentic," she said.   Nokia spokeswoman Han Ying said the battery that exploded labeled Nokia was counterfeit.   The batteries are the latest in a parade of unsafe goods from China, including poison pet food, fake blood protein and dangerous toys.   Chinese imports accounted for more than 60% of the recalls announced by the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission this year, and all of the 24 toy recalls.   China recently announced that nearly 20% of consumer goods it tested in the domestic market failed quality trials.   The mobile phone tests by Guangdong officials came as Chinese authorities investigate the death of a welder, who police say died when a Motorola phone exploded in his chest pocket.   A Motorola spokesman said that the company was helping with the investigation in Gansu province, and that it was "highly unlikely" that one of the company's products was to blame.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 04:23 ET (08:23 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) The New Face Of Janus -2-
Story: One part of the company that doesn't need fixing is Enhanced Investment Technologies, a quantitative manager based in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Since 2002, Janus has owned a majority stake in Intech, as it's known, which appeals to institutional investors. Intech generated $44.1 billion in net cash inflows from Jan. 1, 2003, through this year's first quarter, according to Goldman Sachs. Excluding Intech, Janus had net outflows of about $80 billion in that period.   Janus, long identified as a retail shop, hopes to make more inroads with institutional investors with its core funds. "There's actually not a ton of high-quality institutionally oriented growth managers," observes consultant Quirk. The key to getting more of that business is a strong performance record, stretching over at least three years. Here, Janus has been making progress.   Janus Twenty, led by Schoelzel since 1997, crystallizes the topsy-turvy ride Janus had in the past decade. A high-flyer in the late 1990s, it racked up double-digit losses in 2000, 2001 and 2002. Now that enough time has passed, its five-year annual return of 14.79% beats its benchmark, the S&P 500, by 3.74 percentage points and ranks in the top 4% of the Morningstar large-cap growth category. The fund, which is closed to new investors, has made some good calls in recent years, including on energy and, more recently, on agriculture stocks. Schoelzel's top holdings as of May 31 included Goldman Sachs (GS), Google (GOOG) and Wells Fargo (WFC).   Another highly ranked large-cap growth fund -- and one with a different investment style -- is Janus Research (JAMRX). Run by Jim Goff, it invests mainly in stocks picked by Janus' analysts, rather than its portfolio chief. Its five-year annual return of 13.1% bests its benchmark, the S&P, by more than two percentage points. The fund ranks in the top 11% of the Morningstar large-cap growth group.   In contrast, two of the firm's flagships -- Worldwide and Janus -- remain works in progress. After Yee took over Worldwide nearly three years ago, he slashed its holdings from around 140 to roughly 70, thus allowing it to make larger individual wagers. Yee ratcheted down the firm's exposure to emerging markets, energy and commodities. At first, that hobbled performance. But more recently, his tinkering has begun to pay off. The fund's one-year return of 34.08% puts it in the top 10% of Morningstar's world stock group. Yee takes a philosophical view: "You try to focus on the things you can control -- being disciplined about your process, trying to get things as right as you can and, most important to me, not losing money." A contrarian stockpicker, he likes Dell and some U.S. home builders, including Pulte Homes (PHM), Lennar (LEN) and Centex (CTX).   Corkins, who previously had run the Janus Research Fund, took over the Janus Fund early last year. He immediately trimmed its holdings and lately has been producing decent numbers. This year, it's up 11.23%, about two percentage points ahead of the S&P.   Other Janus funds with excellent three- and five-year returns, relative to their rivals, are Janus Orion (JORNX), a mid-cap growth offering; Janus Overseas (JAOSX) and Janus Growth and Income (JAGIX).   As a company Janus still has a lot to accomplish, first and foremost restoring credibility. That's particularly important because it is moving away from the direct- distribution model that worked so well in the 1990s to reliance on sales by third parties, such as financial advisers and brokers. But building relationships with such people takes time.   Perhaps inevitably, given the company's struggles and its sizable managed assets, some investors wonder whether Janus will stay independent. Occasional speculation about a possible takeover probably is a factor in the asset manager's rich stock valuation. At their recent quote around 30 -- well below their 2000 peak around 55 -- Janus shares trade around a 31 multiple, based on expected 2007 earnings, versus about 22 for T. Rowe Price.   Industry members say that Madison Dearborn Partners, a Chicago private-equity firm that recently agreed to buy Nuveen Investments (JNC), considered taking Janus private. Black maintains that Janus is poised to grow and thrive on its own.   In fact, Janus will have to close some of its top-performing funds, which are attracting too much money to stay efficient. One candidate: Contrarian, which could reach its capacity within a year. That magnifies the importance of developing new funds, such as Janus Advisor Long/Short (JALSX).   Janus still has a way to go. But with growth stocks poised to make a comeback after many years in the doldrums, the company's funds should prosper. If that occurs, Janus' own shares should do well, too, although, given their currently high valuation, it's hard to see them moving much higher anytime soon. Anyone interested in them probably should buy only on a pullback.   If the funds and Janus don't fare well, there's downside protection for the stock, in the possibility of a takeover deal or buyout. In the short run, Janus' funds look like better investments than its shares. In the long run, patient investors are likely to do better with the stock, one way or the other.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : ComEd Prepares for Heavy Weekend Demand for Electricity, Offers Energy-Saving Tips for Customers
Story: High Temperatures Expected Through the Weekend       CHICAGO, July 7 /PRNewswire/ -- With temperatures forecasted in the 90s for Chicago and Northern Illinois this weekend, ComEd is taking additional measures to prepare for heavy electricity demand, including:          -- Postponing scheduled work that would require equipment to be out of         service      -- Scheduling extra work crews, where appropriate, to handle any problems         that may occur; and      -- Putting work crews in the field to monitor the system and respond         quickly to any problems.       As always, ComEd will closely monitor its electric system throughout the weekend. The company will remain in contact with area public officials should any potential problems arise.     Customers are reminded that help with summer electric bills is available through ComEd's three year, $64 million Rate Relief and Assistance Initiative. Through this program ComEd has granted more than 400,000 bill credits totaling $17.9 million to qualifying customers. For more details on ComEd's Rate Relief and Assistance Initiative, visit http://www.ComEdCARE.com, or call 888-806-CARE (2273).     Rate relief grants, credits and other programs are available now to customers most in need. For most programs, customers with incomes up to 200 percent of the poverty level, or $40,000 for a family of four, qualify. In addition, a residential special hardship fund is open to families with incomes up to 400 percent of the poverty level, or $80,000 for a family of four. Enrollment is now open, and ComEd encourages all customers who think that they may be eligible to apply.     To help customers stay comfortable, conserve energy and manage electricity bills during the weekend heat wave, ComEd offers the following energy-saving steps that can save up to 15 percent on home energy costs:          1. Keep thermostats at a constant, comfortable level (75 - 78 degrees)         when at home.  Lowering the thermostat setting below the desired         temperature will not cool the home faster.      2. To reduce heat and moisture during the warmest part of the day, run         appliances such as ovens, washing machines, dryers and dishwashers in         the early morning or evening hours when it's generally cooler outside.         Also, use a microwave to cook, or barbecue outside, if possible.      3. Keep shades, blinds and curtains closed. About 40 percent of unwanted         heat comes through windows. Simply drawing blinds and curtains, which         act as a layer of insulation, can reduce heat gain to your home.         Awnings are even better, and can reduce heat gain by up to 75 percent.         Window coatings and window film can reflect as much as 80 percent of         direct rays from the sun.      4. Turn off all unnecessary lighting and appliances, which add heat to the         home.      5. Keep doors to the outside, garage or attic firmly closed to keep cool         air in and hot air out.      6. Use fans to evenly distribute cool air and reduce the air conditioners         "on" time.       For more energy-saving ideas visit http://www.ComEdCARE.com, or call 888-806-CARE (2273).     Commonwealth Edison Company (ComEd) is a unit of Chicago-based Exelon Corporation (NYSE: EXC), one of the nation's largest electric utilities with approximately 5.4 million customers. ComEd provides service to approximately 3.8 million customers across Northern Illinois, or 70 percent of the state's population.    SOURCE  ComEd       /CONTACT: ComEd Media Relations, +1-312-394-3500      /Web site: http://www.exeloncorp.com      /Web site: http://www.ComEdCARE.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 07:00 ET (11:00 GMT)

Headline: UK's ABF Seeks Successor For Chief At Primark - Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Associated British Foods PLC (ABF.LN) is searching for a replacement for veteran retailer Arthur Ryan as the head of Primark, its fastest growing fashion chain, The Financial Times reported Saturday, citing retail sources.   The food producer and retailer has hired Odgers Ray & Berndtson to conduct the search for a successor to Ryan, the paper said.   The former retail director at Marks and Spencer (MAKSY), Anthony Thompson, is thought to have been in for talks, the paper reported.     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9413     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 07:46 ET (11:46 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Delphi Sees Having 4,703 UAW Members By Yr End, 2,300 By 2012
Story: TROY, Mich. (AP)--Struggling automobile parts maker Delphi Corp. (DPH) expects to have as few as about 2,300 United Auto Workers union members at its four remaining UAW plants by 2012, the company said in a court filing.   That would be less than a tenth of the 24,000 UAW members it employed when it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 2005.   Since that filing, Delphi said its UAW membership has dropped to about 17,000 due to buyouts and early retirements, and by the end of this year, it expects to have 4,703 UAW employees as it closes and sells plants. Total UAW employment could drop to as low as 2,306 in 2012, it said this past week in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court filing in New York. Delphi is the former parts-making division of General Motors Corp. (GM).   Delphi spokesman Lindsey Williams noted that the company earlier had announced its intention to exit most of its core businesses.   Members of the UAW, Delphi's largest union, approved a contract last month that cuts wages for many longtime workers but secures thousands of jobs.   The pact would leave Delphi operating four UAW plants: Grand Rapids; Kokomo, Ind.; Lockport, N.Y.; and Rochester, N.Y.   Delphi plans to sell, close or consolidate plants in Ohio, Alabama, Indiana and Texas.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 13:57 ET (17:57 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) Gilead's War On AIDS
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jay Palmer   Heart disease, cancer and starvation all rank high in the global mortality statistics -- but few modern medical afflictions spark more horror than HIV/AIDS. Though to some degree in check in the Western world, where both death rates and new infections are trending lower, the disease continues to ravage Africa and the less-developed nations -- and few see improvement anytime soon.   As twisted as it may seem for anyone to benefit from such a vast human tragedy, it is nonetheless accurate to point out that shareholders of Gilead Sciences, a sizable Foster City, Calif., biotech company, are doing just that. Its shares climbed more than 40% in the past year and look to be headed considerably higher.   Gilead (ticker: GILD) has quietly emerged as the pharmaceutical leader in the worldwide battle against HIV -- and its fast-growing sales reflect its prime role in fighting this viral disease. In the first quarter of this year, the company's four HIV drugs delivered $705 million in revenue, 70% of the company's total. That represents an increase of 10% over the previous quarter's level and 56% over the year-earlier numbers. Since the fall of 2004, in fact, Gilead's HIV franchise has grown at a compound annual rate of more than 50%.   Most of the torrid growth comes from three drugs --  Truvada, Viread and Emtriva -- all single-pill fixed-dose combinations of anti-HIV drugs that have proved popular not only because they work but because they reduce the previously huge multi-pill burden on patients. Truvada is now used in more than 80% of all new-patient therapy starts.   Gilead also is benefiting from the recent, runaway success of Atripla, another anti-HIV drug that, just nine months after its launch, posted quarterly sales of $190 million, far exceeding Wall Street and industry estimates and almost topping Truvada's U.S. sales. Some 70% of the new Atripla patients were switched from other drugs, mostly GlaxoSmithKline's (GSK) Combivir regimes.   Though the HIV franchise is sure to remain central, Gilead has wisely opted to added other arrows to its quiver. One of the more important is the royalty income it receives for a drug designed to combat bird flu. The company developed Tamiflu, in partnership with Roche (ROG.Switzerland), and it is being stockpiled by governments and organizations around the world to combat what many see as an inevitable global outbreak of influenza. Already, Tamiflu accounts for nearly 20% of company revenues. And every new scare (the latest being last week's finding that three swans in eastern France were killed by the deadly strain of the virus) boosts demands for stockpiling.   Not resting on any laurels, Gilead owns an impressive new-drug pipeline. Following FDA approval last month, the company has launched Letairis, a compound designed to treat pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). Though PAH is a relatively rare condition, with no more than 200,000 sufferers worldwide, the potential market is put close to $2 billion. It's not unreasonable to expect Gilead to eventually win a 25% market share, meaning $500 million in annual sales.   The acquisitions last year of Myogen for $2.5 billion and Corus Pharma for $365 million have put the company in new areas, including a treatment for cystic fibrosis. Since Gilead has a large war chest of close to $2 billion, further acquisitions that expand its product line in both existing and new markets are more likely than not. Asked if the firm is planning additional acquisitions or would rather buy back stock, CEO John Martin, 56, quips "All of the above."   Gilead itself could become a takeover target, but with a stock-market value of $36 billion, it would probably attract only the largest buyers. Acquirers also might be put off by the constant spotlight of protesters, who seem convinced that the company shouldn't be allowed to make any profit from its AIDS products.   Gilead's financials are attractive. This year, revenue probably will rise by 35%, to about $4 billion (with three-quarters of that coming from HIV products). Earnings are also headed higher, suggests Eun Yang of Jefferies, perhaps to $1.50 to $1.55 a share this year, a 25% gain over '06. Profits could well hit $2 a share by 2009.   Even after the stock's runup, to about 39, it is trading at 25 times 2007 earnings, in line with industry giant Genentech's (DNA) multiple and not hugely rich, considering Gilead's growth potential. Some analysts think it could reach 48 within a year.   "For the past 20 years, I have been asked every year if the growth now will slow," observes Martin. "It hasn't and won't. I continue to see developing value for stockholders. I continue to see a very exciting future for this company."   Disease -- and its amelioration -- can be profitable.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: INTERVIEW: ING Still On Lookout For Add-On Buys - CEO
Story: By Nicolas Parasie     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     AIX-EN-PROVENCE, FRANCE (Dow Jones)--The chief executive of financial services giant ING Groep NV (ING) reiterated that the company is in no rush to carry out a large deal and will instead continue to consider mostly add-on acquisitions in emerging markets in the near future.   The Dutch banking and insurance group has been very active in recent months, announcing the acquisition of Oyak Bank in Turkey and an asset manager in South Korea, as well as a EUR5 billion share buyback and a revamp of its domestic retail bank. It looked into buying ABN Amro Holding NV (ABN), its underperforming domestic rival that is now subject to two competing bids and faces a likely breakup.   "Our strategy remains the same," Michel Tilmant said in an interview. The Amsterdam-based group will continue to bolster its life insurance, asset management and banking activities in faster-growing markets. "We still look at complimentary buys in those markets," he said.   The flurry of deals recently announced by ING follows a relatively quiet period of several years during which ING's Belgian CEO mostly focused on streamlining the company by offloading nearly two dozen subsidiaries.   Despite posting strong results in recent years, often boosted by Internet banking unit ING Direct, some industry observers question the group's bank-insurance model, even suggesting a break up.   Asked whether ING could also be the target of activist shareholders, Tilmant said the company constantly reviews its activities and tries to assure shareholders it makes good use of its capital. "The key thing is to review our portfolio and to make sure we allocate our capital well," he said.   Tilmant also stressed that the term "bank-insurer" didn't fully cover the group's activities.   "We should get out of the bank-insurer description. It doesn't reflect properly what we are doing," Tilmant said.     Company Web site: http://www.ing.com     - By Nicolas Parasie, Dow Jones Newswires; +33 1 40 17 1770; nicolas.parasie@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 08:47 ET (12:47 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Boeing, ALAFCO Sign for 10 Additional 787s
Story: SEATTLE, July 7 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Boeing (NYSE: BA) and ALAFCO Aviation Lease and Finance Company of Kuwait today held a formal signing ceremony for the direct purchase of 10 787-8 Dreamliners. The deal was completed the day before the public Premiere of Boeing's first 787 in Everett, Wash.     Valued at $1.62 billion at list prices, the new purchase builds on an order for 12 787s ALAFCO announced in March 2007.     The Sharia-based leasing and finance company was the first Middle East customer to finalize its order for the highly sought-after Dreamliner, and ALAFCO has successfully placed its first 12 787s with Kuwait Airways.     Scott Carson, Boeing Commercial Airplanes president and CEO, hosted today's event at Seattle's Harbor Club, where guest of honor Mr. Ahmad Alzabin, ALAFCO's chairman and CEO, signed the order for the additional airplanes.     "We're proud to be the first Middle Eastern company to purchase the 787-8 and we're extremely pleased to have quickly placed all of the 787s in our initial order with Kuwait Airways," said Mr. Alzabin. "We have decided to move quickly on acquiring additional 787s as we see continued strong market demand for this revolutionary airplane and we wish to offer airlines the airplane that is setting new standards in operational efficiency and reliability."     ALAFCO became a publicly traded company in October 2006. It currently has airplanes on lease with nine carriers worldwide.     "Our strong association with ALAFCO, as well as having 787s flying with Kuwait Airways, truly demonstrates Boeing's focus in the Middle East market," said Carson. "We are determined to build upon our regional relationships to establish an even stronger foundation for future business -- one that will continue to focus on meeting our customers' expectations and providing airplanes and services that help them be successful."     Boeing reorganized its sales regions in 2005 and deployed a specialized Middle East team that has led to a dramatic turnaround of the company's market share of commercial airplanes sold in the region.     Since launch in April 2004, the Boeing 787 Dreamliner has logged orders from 46 customers for 652 airplanes, making it the most successful launch of a commercial airplane in Boeing's history. First flight is scheduled for later this year followed by certification and first delivery in May 2008.    SOURCE  Boeing       /CONTACT: Brian Walker of Boeing Commercial Airplanes Middle East & Africa Communications, +1-206-356-4606; or Adam Morgan of 787 Program Communications, +1-425-294-6103, for Boeing      /Web site: http://www.boeing.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 16:59 ET (20:59 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(7/9) The Sharpest Tool In The Shed
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Christopher C. Williams   Investors are building positions in the shares of heavy-equipment makers, betting that the worldwide boom in infrastructure will mean even bigger business for companies such as McDermott International (ticker: MDR) and Parker Hannifin (PH).   Illinois Tool Works (ITW), a diversified manufacturer, is winning its share of fans, as well, with a stock that has risen 20% this year, to 55. They believe the company's growth-by-acquisition strategy will produce another year ofstellar earnings, helping the conglomerate outrun the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index in 2007, as it has for the past 20 years. If the global economy stays strong, encouraging more development in Asia and elsewhere, Illinois Tool easily could rally into the low 60s in the next year, on solid quarterly results.   Dubbed "one of the sharpest tools in the shed" by Morningstar, the Glenview, Ill.-based company has produced double-digit earnings gains in the past 10 years, and is on track to do so again. Citing more than $1 billion of potential acquisitions and a growing international operation, analysts expect Illinois Tool to earn $3.33 a share this year, up from $3.01 in '06, on a 14% increase in revenue to almost $16 billion. Though acquisitions will account for much of that growth, better-than-expected organic growth also could boost results.   Notwithstanding its bright prospects, Illinois Tool trades for only 15 times consensus 2008 earnings projections of $3.72 a share, about 10% below the price-earnings multiples afforded diversified industrial multinationals such as Danaher (DHR), notes Goldman Sachs analyst Deane Dray. "It's exceptionally attractive," he says. "It has had a nice pop, but has a lot more room to run."   Dray calls his one-year price target of 61 "conservative." Given Illinois Tool's consistent earnings performance and sturdy balance sheet, he argues that the stock justifiably could be valued at a 10% premium to peers sector. That would translate into a P/E of 18 and a price of 67.   Founded in 1912 as a maker of metal-cutting tools, Illinois Tool now offers a dizzying array of products for the automotive, construction and food and beverage industries. It sells, among other things, fasteners, welding machines and plastic ring carriers for beverage cans. It has bought about 32 companies a year over the past 10 years, each averaging  about $32 million in yearly sales. Last year, it scooped up a record 53 companies representing $1.7 billion in annualized revenue, a pace some analysts think it could match this year. Since 1982, return on invested capital has averaged 15%.   Illinois Tool is ultra-lean; only about 50 executives in the corporate center oversee 750 units in the U.S. and 48 foreign countries. Led by David Speer, 56, a 28-year company veteran who became CEO in 2005, its managers are expert in "80/20," meaning they concentrate the company's resources on the 20% of customers and products that deliver 80% of a unit's sales. Company officials were unavailable to comment.   Daniel Dowd of Bernstein Research suspects that Illinois Tool would enjoy a higher multiple if its business model were better understood. "ITW's competitive advantage lies in its ability to create value through world-class capital allocation, and in identifying and systematically improving very small acquisitions," he observes.   Dowd also thinks that Illinois Tool is less exposed to the North American new-home and auto markets than some investors believe. In the first quarter, a 20% drop in its North American housing sales and a 7% slip in its auto business understandably focused investors' attention. But other operations, such as international welding, grew a healthy 21%, helping Illinois Tool produce on-target results. Those trends probably continued in the second quarter, ended last month, in which analysts figure the company earned 88 cents a share, up from 81 cents a year earlier. Illinois Tool reports results next Thursday.   Dowd notes that the U.S. housing and auto markets represent just 13% of Illinois Tool's revenue, and that the company sells to many other customers, including renovation-construction specialists and foreign original-equipment manufacturers, that are counter-cyclical to those troublesome areas. He believes stronger-than-expected second-half results will convince skeptics that Illinois Tool will weather the downturns in housing and auto in fine shape, and help push the stock toward his 68 price target. "ITW has and will continue to grow with the global economy," he says.   Growth could be pinched if the pool of attractive acquisition candidates dries up, but that is unlikely to happen, at least in the near term. Besides, Illinois Tool has other, yes, tools, at its disposal to keep shareholders happy; among them, the company could use its copious cash flow --  $1.8 billion last year -- to repurchase shares.   As its customers might say, don't underestimate the value of a well-stocked tool kit. Or, a well-run company.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) Plugged In: Half-Time Report
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   Independence Day is just about the half-way mark for the year. And like baseball's All-Star break -- which is centered on this week's game here in San Francisco -- the Fourth of July holiday provided a break, with time for reflection.   One of the stories I've wanted to follow up is that of Neutral Tandem, a telecom start-up I wrote about a year ago (Plugged In, June 5, 2006). At the time, I mentioned that we rarely write about private companies, but that this one wasworth discussing.   I still feel that way. Neutral Tandem filed to go public earlier this year, with Morgan Stanley as its lead  underwriter. There's no word yet on when the IPO will occur or the preliminary pricing terms. And the company can't comment because of the quiet period.   But the Chicago-based outfit deserves to be mentioned in any conversation about two other deals that have gotten more play: last week's filing by on-demand software provider NetSuite, which we anticipated in last week's column, and the forthcoming partial spin-out of VMware from EMC (ticker: EMC).   This one was different from most start-ups. It had experienced management, real revenue and was committed to a significant capital build-out across a broad swath of geography.   Since launching its service in February 2004, the company has grown like gangbusters, generating about $28 million in fiscal 2005 revenue. During the nine months ended Sept. 30, 2006, Neutral Tandem racked up $37.9 million in revenue, an increase of 108% compared with the previous nine months' total. On top of that, the company is in the black, having made $6.2 million in the first nine months of 2006, according to the filing.   Like many companies with promise, Neutral Tandem was founded to solve a problem: fixing interconnection problems among wireless, wireline, cable, Internet and other telecom carriers. It also helps exchange voice traffic among competitors. The company claims to be the country's largest network providing neutral interconnection points for voice traffic among rival carriers. It has deals with 56 major players, including AT&T (T), Sprint Nextel (S) and Comcast Cable Communications (CMCSA).   Last month, Ernst & Young gave Neutral Tandem management one of its coveted regional entrepreneurs of the year awards. These guys definitely bear watching.   Since I'm seizing this opportunity to follow up on previous columns, it looks as if Openwave System's (OPWV) chances of being bought or merged have waned significantly since my first item (Plugged In, March 12).   In June, Harbinger Capital opted to take its ball and go home. After amassing about a 13.4% stake, the activist hedge fund announced that it is no longer trying to buy 49% of the sputtering software firm Harbinger had launched a tender offer for 40.4 million shares at $8.30 each, but it failed to secure the necessary threshold number. Harbinger wanted to merge Openwave with a privately held communications software company, but Openwave's directors rejected the idea amid hopes of more lucrative takeover offers by larger tech companies, which never materialized. Openwave shares have plunged to around 6 after trading as high as 10.51 in early June.   ---   E-mail: mark.veverka@barrons.com   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Orient Express Tipped Next Hotel Buyout Target - Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Orient-Express Hotels LTD (OEH), the company that owns the eponymous train and some of the world's most luxurious hotels, is being tipped as the next bid target in a sector attracting private equity interest, The Times reported Saturday without citing sources.   Financial predators, including an unnamed U.S. hedge fund and Sharewood Capital, which has a 4% stake, are understood to have checked out the New York-listed group in recent months, the newspaper reported.   Blackstone Group (BX) and Morgan Stanley (MS) are also have thought to have looked at the business, according to the paper.     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9413     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 07:33 ET (11:33 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) Speaking Of Dividends: Payout Hikes Slip 7.2%: But Total Of Companies Declaring Dividends Rises
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   Of the approximately 7,000 companies covered by Standard & Poor's survey of second-quarter dividend activity, 448 hiked their payouts, 7.2% fewer than the 483 that did so a year earlier. This was the fourth consecutive quarterly year-over-year decline. The drop was especially disturbing "in light of the continued, moderate earnings growth and the abundance of corporate cash," says S&P senior index analyst Howard Silverblatt.   In the first half, the number of dividend boosts fell 3.6%, to 1,069 from 1,109. In the corresponding 2006 stretch, the total was up 5%.   On the brighter side, extra dividends rose to 92 from 89 in the quarter. The six-month total was 203, versus 192 -- a 5.7% advance. Companies paying extras might have sweetened their regular payouts but chose also to pay a bonus because they had additional cash. Or they simply might want to play it safe by not committing to a bigger regular dividend that might prove unsustainable.   Another positive: The total of dividend payers is rising, reports S&P. Through June 30, nearly 3% more companies had declared payouts than in 2006's first six months.   And 10 companies have resumed paying dividends this year, matching the year-earlier showing.   Stock splits have become rarer, S&P notes. Through June, 259 companies had divided their shares, compared with 360 and 400, respectively, in 2006's and 2005's first halves. S&P figures that the decline in splits boosted the average share price to $33.19 last month from $27.58 in June 2006 and $25.76 in June 2005. "Clearly, companies are becoming more comfortable with higher stock prices," concludes Silverblatt.   As for dividend cuts, S&P counted nine in the second quarter. That was down from 13 in the first quarter, but double the four in 2006's second quarter.   Twenty-two companies cut their payouts in the latest quarter, versus 15 a year earlier. In the half, 15 companies trimmed their distributions -- against 16 in 2006's initial six months.   All the dividend activity among the 65 stocks in the Dow Jones averages in the second quarter involved increases. Peter Miller, Barron's statistics director, counted eight enhancements among the industrials: American International Group (ticker: AIG), Caterpillar (CAT), ExxonMobil (XOM), International Business Machines (IBM), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Procter & Gamble (PG) and United Technologies (UTX). The group as a whole paid out $70.09 in dividends, up 9.7% from $63.89 in the April-June 2006 stretch. Yield: 2.09%.   Coca-Cola (KO) and Wal-Mart paid sweetened dividends last quarter, but had declared them in the year's first three months. The payment dates for AIG, Cat, JPMorgan Chase and United Technologies are in the third quarter.   Moving on to the 20 transports, they distributed $14.34 in the second quarter, by Miller's calculation, 19.2% above the $12.03 of a year earlier, for a 1.04% yield. A quintet of boosts were provided by Alexander & Baldwin (ALEX), CSX (CSX), Expeditors International (EXPD), FedEx (FDX) and Overseas Shipholding (OSG). Union Pacific (UNP) approved a hike in the first quarter, but paid it in the second. And the new CSX, FedEx and Overseas Shipholding dividends go out this quarter.   Among the 15 Dow utilities, Duke Energy (DUK), Southern Co. (SO) and Williams Cos. (WMB) declared hikes, although Duke won't make its payout until September. Yielding 2.95%, the group's total dividends rose 5.60%, to $3.77 from $3.57. PG&E (PCG) paid a higher dividend in April, but had declared it in the first quarter.   To get the full-return picture, here's how each of the Dow groups did pricewise in 2007's second-quarter: industrials, up 8.53%; transports, up 5.99%; utilities, down 0.40%.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) European Trader: Sovereign Funds Could Face A Backlash
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Matthew Curtin and Sean Walters   EADs categorized dubai international capital as just another institutional investor after the fund bought a 3.1% stake in the aero-defense company.   How wrong EADS (ticker: EAD.France) is. This $802 million investment reflects a major shift in global capital markets that isn't necessarily benign. It's a function of soaring commodity prices, the industrialization of much of Asia and the determination of Asian central banks to maintain weak currencies. All this has ledto a massive accumulation of foreign-exchange reserves, in the Middle East, Russia, China and other non-Western nations.   The countries with the swelling coffers seem increasingly keen to get a better return on money that they've until recently plowed into U.S. Treasuries and euro-denominated bonds. The obvious solution: invest in equities. This provides diversification, plus a bigger share of the profits generated by globalization, visible in robust earnings growth at U.S. and European multinationals.   Such are resources at these countries' disposal -- China's foreign-exchange reserves stood at $1.2 trillion on March 31 -- that their sovereign wealth funds can pretty much take their pick of what they want to buy. If the investment is carried out transparently, and the criteria are financial or industrial, that's not necessarily a problem and it won't raise nationalist hackles in the target countries.   Dubai International Capital's EADS investment fits the bill. Dubai is a small country staking its future in part on development of a soundly regulated local financial market and a role as a global transport hub. State-owned airline Emirates is a key customer of EADS' Airbus unit.   But others' motives may be more sinister, especially when strategic assets are in play. Take the 5% stake in EADS held by OAO Bank VTB, the state-owned Russian lender. EADS is a major supplier to the armies of NATO, whose eastward expansion has so unnerved Moscow. It's hard to see VTB"s interest in EADS as purely financial.   Suspicions about such investments adds to the danger that the West will become increasingly protectionist. That danger is already apparent in the trouble that Chinese and Dubai investors have had in investing in the U.S., and in the jettisoning of a commitment to open markets in the main text of the European Union's new trade treaty.   Protectionism is the wrong approach. Reciprocity, with minimal obstacles to capital flows, is what the U.S. and Europe should demand of emerging-market countries, many of which have proved only too eager to join the World Trade Organization.   But as the sovereign wealth funds of China, Russia and other countries flex their financial muscles, there's the dispiriting prospect of a more protectionist world.   Fiat reckons that it can emulate the success BMW has had with the Mini in exploiting drivers' nostalgia for old brands by going retro itself with its new-look Fiat 500.   But it's far from certain that Fiat (F.Italy) has the winning formula, considering the mixed fortunes Volkswagen has had in trying to pull off the same trick with the Beetle.   Without a hit similar to BMW's (BMW.Germany) Mini, Fiat's shares will look distinctly expensive. After all, plenty of good news is already built into a stock that's trading at 16 times 2007 estimated earnings, an 11% premium to the rest of the sector. The Italian auto maker's shares have risen more than 120% in the past year. (Last week, Fiat's American depositary shares, traded on the Big Board under the ticker symbol FIA, hit a 52-week high of $31.72.)   Fiat's strategy for the 500 is to market the small car at a premium price. Analysts think Fiat could sell 200,000 Fiat 500s in 2008 at around 12,000 euros ($16,300) each. Pencil in a profit margin of about 5% -- Fiat's making the cars in Poland -- larger than the usual 2% or 3% for small cars, and the resulting 120 million euros would have a significant impact on Fiat's bottom-line. Fiat earned 1.07 billion euros in 2006.   But with the 500, Fiat is gambling that consumers will pay a premium price for a car that lacks a premium nameplate. VW (VOW.Germany) knows that's not easy. The German auto maker cut the Beetle's price last year to try to reverse declining sales. Even initial sales of the retro car were disappointing.   Even if the 500 is a big hit, maintaining Fiat's European market share is likely to become more difficult because some of its success reflects weakness among its main competitors. Now they're fighting back. While Fiat plans to launch 23 new models by 2010, Peugeot (UG.France) plans 41. Renault (RNO.France) will have 20 new models in showrooms by 2009. And Asian car companies are making steady inroads in Europe.   So at their current lofty price, Fiat's shares might be suitable only for enthusiasts of Italian auto-making.   ---   Matthew Curtin, who reports from Paris, and Sean Walters, who is based in London, contribute to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column on which this European Trader is based.   ---                       DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES     Region/   Country    DJ Global          DJ Global           DJ Global     Point     Indexes,           Indexes,            Indexes,      Chg.    % Chg.
