Headline: Barron's(7/9) At The Center Of The Closed-End Fund Universe
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lawrence C. Strauss   Interview With Thomas J. Herzfeld   Founder, Thomas J. Herzfeld & Co.     After a brief stay in his family's textile business, Thomas J. Herzfeld discovered his true calling in the late 1960s at an unlikely venue: a New York brokerage firm's training program. A session on closed-end funds fascinated him because "they offered investors the opportunity to buy assets at a discount." Now 62, Herzfeld has been pursuing that opportunity for 40 years, becoming one of thenation's foremost experts on the subject. The author of several books, including Encyclopedia of Closed-End Funds, now advises institutional and retail clients on his favorite topic.   Unlike open-end mutual funds, closed-ends have a fixed number of shares that trade on an exchange. The share prices typically trade at a discount or a premium to their underlying net asset value, depending on investor sentiment about their assets. In contrast, investors in an open-end fund buy and redeem shares directly from the fund. That can force the portfolio manager to sell some holdings to raise cash for redemptions or to buy more if new money flows in. Closed-end managers needn't worry about any of that. In all, closed-end funds oversee $312 billion, compared with $11.4 trillion in mutual funds and $485 billion in a new rival: exchange-traded funds.   Based in Miami, Herzfeld founded Thomas J. Herzfeld & Co., a brokerage specializing in closed-ends, in 1981, and launched a similarly focused money-management arm, Thomas J. Herzfeld Advisors, in 1984. The firm oversees about $100 million in assets. The Managed Portfolio I, a separate-account program created by the advisory firm in 1987, invests in bond and stock closed-end funds. It has a cumulative total return since inception of 509%, net of fees, versus nearly 400% for the S&P 500.   Herzfeld also runs the novel Herzfeld Caribbean Basin Fund (ticker: CUBA), which invests in companies with direct and indirect ties to Cuba and has gained more attention in the past year as Fidel Castro's health has deteriorated.   For more about Herzfeld's start, his views on pricing and activists, as well as other topics -- including some closed-ends he likes and some he doesn't -- read on.     Barron's: We're told that as a kid in school, you weren't at the top of the class.   Herzfeld: I was probably near the bottom, barely graduated from high school and only was admitted to college thanks to some favors [owed] to my father.     Q: And then you studied to be a textile engineer?   A: Yes, the school I attended, the Philadelphia College of Textiles & Science, now Philadelphia University, was primarily known for its textile engineering and chemistry programs. They did, however, offer a few business courses, which I managed to take.     Q: Anyone have a big influence on you?   A: There was Bob Parry, a Ph.D. candidate at the University of Pennsylvania who was teaching courses in money, banking and economics. He later became president of the Federal Reserve Bank in San Francisco. He had quite a large influence on me.     Q: What did you do after college?   A: I went into the family textile business, but that didn't last long. Then I went off to Wall Street as a trainee with Reynolds & Co., a brokerage firm, and I applied to business schools. I started at the Bernard Baruch School at City College of New York and then my Army reserve unit was called up briefly, so I never continued.     Q: When did you get the bug for closed-end funds?   A: Reynolds had a very formal training program where they brought in professors and experts, including lectures on open-end and closed-end funds. I found it fascinating that closed-end funds offered investors the opportunity to buy assets at a discount, and I was captivated by that right from the beginning.     Q: In those days, relative to the open-end fund business, closed-ends were small, right?   A: Yes, you could almost keep track of them in your head. There were 60 funds with $8 billion in assets, and I probably became the leading expert on the subject for no other reason than I was the only one interested in it. I used to give lectures to get accounts.     Q: Let's talk about the history of closed-end funds, which in the U.S. date to the 1920s.   A: That's right in the U.S., but they really date to the late 19th century. There were closed-end funds formed in England and Scotland to invest in the New World, both the U.S. and South America.     Q: What about in the United States?   A: Closed-end funds proliferated in the 1920s, especially in 1929 just before the Crash. They were leveraged, and they were able to buy shares in each other. There were people who were using one fund's assets to take control of another fund. After the Crash, most of them went bankrupt. In the recovery years and to this date, closed-end funds were never able to attain attention and size, relative to the mutual-fund industry.     Q: Why?   A: Well, mutual funds advertise, and closed-end funds basically do not.     Q: Are they are restricted from advertising?   A: No, it is just a matter of who is going to pay for it. Whose money would they spend to advertise a closed-end fund? But with open-end mutual funds, the managers are allowed to spend shareholders' money to advertise and grow the funds.     Q: Are exchange-traded funds a threat?   A: It depends on how you define a threat. In terms of the discounts to net asset value, many thought that the ETFs could cause the discounts in closed-end funds to widen. I would say it is more common now to find closed-end-fund discounts narrowing because of the introduction of similar ETFs.     Q: What do you attribute that to?   A: Activists and takeover traders now can buy closed-end funds at deep discounts and hedge their market risk by selling short ETFs, which actually helps the valuations of closed-end funds. In terms of competing with them for new money, we are seeing both closed-end funds and ETFs created. And closed-end funds have certain advantages over exchange-traded funds.     Q: Such as?   A: Investing in thinner markets, less liquid markets or foreign markets. Also, they can use leverage and they are continually managed, whereas ETFs aren't managed actively, although this is changing.     Q: There's been a lot of issuance recently in the closed-end market. What kind of impact has that had?   A: It is quite a business for the underwriters and the advisers. It is a very profitable underwriting business. As new funds are created, advisers are getting more and more captive assets, which create advisory fees. So it is a very good business for those people who bring them to market and manage them. From the investor's point of view, many of the new closed-end funds are similar to existing funds. Before investors jump into a new issue, they should see if there is something the same or similar that is trading at a discount to net asset value.     Q: Let's talk about your interest in Cuba and the closed-end you run, the Herzfeld Caribbean Basin Fund, as a way to invest in that country.   A: My interest in Cuba stems from being in Florida for three decades and being immersed in the Cuban-American culture. Many of our friends, clients, neighbors, and school buddies of my children are Cuban- Americans, and they have shared with me their experience. We understand Cuba and the future of free Cuba; it seemed like an excellent idea to form the first fund.     Q: How big is that fund now?   A: About $16.5 million. The market value is higher because it is trading at a premium.     Q: How many holdings does it have?   A: About 75. We are broadly diversified but we have really a two-pronged investment strategy. When we formed the fund, we realized that it would be impossible to predict when the embargo with Cuba would be lifted. It is still unpredictable even 14 years later. So we sought to identify companies with operations in the Caribbean that we believed would do well, even if there were no change with U.S. trade with Cuba. We also sought companies that we believe would get significant increases in business once the embargo was lifted. That was the first phase and we are still in that phase now. [Holdings include Trailer Bridge (TRBR) of Jacksonville, Fla., with operations in the U.S., Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic, and Cuban Electric (CGAR.PK), an American company that Castro confiscated.] Once the embargo is lifted, then we will change the strategy to seek direct investments in Cuba.     Q: For those investors interested in closed-end funds, what's your advice?   A: We analyze 20 to 30 variables when we are making our investment decisions. But to begin, it is discount, discount, discount. We like to buy a closed-end fund that is trading at a wider-than-average discount to its own range -- and also a wider-than-average discount to its peers. And then we look at the other 20 or 30 variables, including performance, income ratio, anti-takeover provisions, windup provisions, lifeboat provisions, liquidity of the portfolio and liquidity of the fund shares. We also consider the attitude of the fund's management concerning the fund's discount, the track record of the management handling the discount and payout policies. Are they invested in in-favor or out-of-favor issues? The most controversial area of the closed-end business currently relates to distributions.     Q: Could you elaborate?   A: The entire way that closed-end funds are now making payouts is very complicated and very controversial and probably could have investors running into trouble if they don't understand the payout process and composition of the payout.     Q: How about an example?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Italian Health Authorities Test Possibly Tainted Toothpaste
Story: ROME (AP)--Italian authorities have seized a few batches of possibly tainted toothpaste in Florence and other cities in the country's north, the Health Ministry said Saturday.   The ministry said checks were being carried out across the country on Colgate toothpaste that was without Italian language labeling.   The seizures of the suspicious toothpaste occurred in Genoa and Aosta as well as in the Tuscan capital, the ministry said in a statement. Samples were being analyzed to see if the toothpaste contained dangerous substances.   No further details were immediately available.   Concern over tainted toothpaste spread over the past weeks in some U.S. states and Canada.   The U.S. Food and Drug Administration said last month that toothpaste from China and counterfeit Colgate toothpaste may contain diethylene glycol, a chemical used in antifreeze.   This week there have been reports in the Spanish media that tainted toothpaste has been detected in the country.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 10:42 ET (14:42 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : DIRECTV 10 Launch A Giant Leap for HD
Story: New Satellite will Begin Unprecedented Expansion of DIRECTV HD   Programming that will Provide Customers with an Industry-Leading               Lineup of Up to 100 National HD Channels  EL SEGUNDO, Calif.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--July 07, 2007--   The DIRECTV 10 satellite soared into space yesterday, beginning the first leg of its mission to dramatically expand HD programming for millions of DIRECTV customers nationwide and establish DIRECTV as the industry's HD pace-setter.     The Boeing-built 702 model satellite lifted off at 6:16 p.m. PDT, Friday, July 6, from Pad 39 at the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan aboard an International Launch Services (ILS) Russian-built Proton Breeze M launch vehicle. After nine hours and eight minutes in flight, the rocket left the spacecraft in a geosynchronous transfer orbit with a high point of 22,300 miles (36,000 km) above the equator. Controllers at the ground station in Hartebeesthoek, South Africa have made contact with the satellite and confirmed that all systems are functioning properly.     After the spacecraft is maneuvered into a circular orbit at 103 degrees West longitude and tests are completed, it is expected to begin operations in early September, delivering the first of up to 100 national HD channels by year-end. The DIRECTV 10 satellite's powerful transponder payload includes spot beam capacity that will enable DIRECTV to expand its local HD channel services to up to 75 markets this year.     "With the successful launch of our DIRECTV 10 satellite, we are, to borrow a phrase, boldly going where no TV service has gone before - a new world of up to 100 HD channels and a viewing experience unmatched in the multichannel video marketplace," said Derek Chang, executive vice president, Content Development and Strategy, DIRECTV, Inc. "We congratulate the Boeing and ILS teams on a flawless launch as we begin the next countdown to September when the first of our new HD channels will be available to our customers."     DIRECTV has agreements in place to rollout multiple HD channels from top content providers such as Disney, Discovery Communications, A&E Television Networks, HBO, Fox, Turner, NBC Universal, Showtime Networks, Starz and Scripps Networks, among others.     An additional satellite, DIRECTV 11, will be launched early next year to support further HD expansion in 2008. Between the two satellites, DIRECTV will be capable of delivering more than 1,500 local HD channels and 150 national HD channels, in addition to new advanced programming services for customers.     DIRECTV 10 is the third DIRECTV satellite launched on an ILS Proton vehicle from the Baikonur Cosmodrome, the oldest space launch facility in the world.       About DIRECTV     DIRECTV, Inc., the nation's leading satellite television service provider, presents the finest television experience available to more than 16 million customers in the United States, through exclusive content, industry-leading customer satisfaction (which has surpassed cable for seven years running) and superior technologies. Each day, DIRECTV subscribers enjoy access to over 250 channels of 100% digital picture and sound, exclusive programming and the most comprehensive collection of sports programming available anywhere, including NFL SUNDAY TICKET(TM) and MLB EXTRA INNINGS(R). DIRECTV (NYSE:DTV) also leads the digital television technology revolution with exclusives such as NFL SUNDAY TICKET SuperFan(TM), US Open Interactive and YES Network Interactive and will soon have the capacity to offer over 150 channels in HD. For the most up-to-date information on DIRECTV, please visit directv.com.        CONTACT: DIRECTV, Inc.               Robert Mercer, 310-964-4683        SOURCE: DIRECTV, Inc. Headline: INTERVIEW: CNP Assurances Eyes Possible Entry Into New Mkt
Story: By Nicolas Parasie     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France (Dow Jones)--French insurance group CNP Assurances (12022.FR) is expected to announce in the following weeks it will enter a new country, either Turkey or Greece, the company's chief executive told Dow Jones Newswires Saturday.   CNP, France's leading life and pensions provider in terms of market share, in recent years has expanded its footprint in Latin America and southeastern Europe. It is active in Portugal, Italy, Spain and Brazil among others.   Chief Executive Gilles Benoist said in an interview that the company is "studying (its) options in the Mediterranean" and hinted at the possibility that CNP would enter either Greece or Turkey. Because a potential deal wasn't finalized yet, Benoist didn't provide any further details.   CNP Assurances, whose main shareholders are state-owned entities Caisse des Depots, Caisse d'Epargne and La Poste, will also present its shareholders a strategy update by the end of the year.   The strategy update for 2008-2012, will more be about fine-tuning existing plans and won't contain huge surprises, as the company's main ambitions haven't changed, Benoist said. CNP still aims at remaining the market leader in France in the life and pensions sector, while at the same time expanding abroad. CNP at the time of its listing in 1998 was only active in the French market. Today, nearly 14% of its profits is generated outside its home market.   "I don't see any reason for any great strategic shift," Benoist said.   He also commented on the group's partnership with Italian bank Capitalia SPA (CAP.MI), which recently was swallowed by domestic peer UniCredito Italiano (UC.MI).   "Its clear that we have the desire to go on with the partnership with Capitalia," Benoist said. He added that existing business agreements were still in place but were going to be renegotiated in the near future.   Asked whether he expected the European industry to undergo a wave of consolidation, Benoist said that "in 2008 there could be big deals," due to the implementation of new regulatory directives on capital requirements such as Basel II and Solvency II.   He also acknowledged that some of Europe's largest insurers, such as Axa SA (AXA) and Allianz (AZ) may be looking out for large deals and that some in the insurance industry expect private equity investors to play a more active role in consolidating the sector.     Company Web site: http://www.cnp.fr     -By Nicolas Parasie, Dow Jones Newswires; nicolas.parasie@dowjones.com; +33 1 40 17 1770     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 08:01 ET (12:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) Barron's Mailbag: History Lesson
Story: (From BARRON'S)   To the Editor:     The June 25 cover story, "Top of the Market," claims that Blackstone is no Goldman Sachs. Let's hope not. The Goldman Sachs Trading Corp. was created in 1928 to offer the investing public an opportunity to share in its financial genius through investment trusts. Sound familiar? By 1930, Goldman Sachs Trading's value had shrunk from $500 million to less than $10 million and the name became a vaudeville punchline from coast to coast.Goldman Sachs maybe more than 100 years old, but the Trading Corp. lasted only three years.   Jay Goerk   Seattle   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:02 ET (04:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) Capturing The Yield From Personal Bonds
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tom Sullivan   It's not easy for a money manager to grow rapidly. It's tougher still to maintain top performance while growing rapidly. The hardest part of this juggling act, however, may be preventing employees from tearing each other -- and the firm -- apart while pulling off the first two. To date at least, Western Asset Management has succeeded at all three.   The bond-investment arm of Baltimore's Legg Mason (ticker: LM) has doubled its assets to $600 billion since 2005, owing mostly to its parent's swap of its brokerage unit for Citigroup's money-management operations. Despite that potential disruption, Western's two signature investment vehicles, the Morningstar five-star-rated Western Asset Core Bond (WATFX) and Western Asset Core Plus (WACPX) funds, have returned 7.38% and 7.06% in the last year, besting better-known rivals like Pimco's Harbor Bond Fund (HABDX) in that time. The basic-core fund includes "plain-vanilla" assets like government bonds, mortgages and other asset-backed securities, as well as corporate bonds; the "plus"-version also includes emerging-market, high-yield and non-dollar assets.   Jim Hirschmann, the 46-year-old CEO of Pasadena, Calif.-based Western, claims his biggest challenge in growing to 1,000 employees in eight offices in seven countries is maintaining a "team-based, collegial" atmosphere. He regards stability as the biggest contributor to Western's performance and, since the swap, the firm hasn't seen a spike in employee turnover.   Of course, it's top-tier performance that keep customers in the fold. Western's philosophy, honed since its founding in 1971, is "very straightforward-value investing," says Ken Leech, the firm's chief investment officer. "It's a research-driven process" that seeks multiple sources of return and is "not too dependent on a macro view."   A key factor in Morningstar's high rating is Western's spending "on research and people and technology to compete," says analyst Paul Herbert, who adds --  unprompted -- that the firm's "collegial" approach helps. In all, Western says it now has more than 100 analysts worldwide.   An added source of support is Western's fixed-income focus, says Hirschmann, who's been with the firm since 1989 and CEO since 1999. "There's no competing businesses, just bonds," he notes.   Although Western historically has been an institutional manager -- running money for the likes of The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and the California Public Employees Retirement System -- the Citigroup swap has broadened its focus to include more retail customers. Only about 8.5% of its assets were retail prior to the deal; afterward the total has increased to roughly 35%. The firm, acquired by Legg Mason in 1986 and then expanded with the purchase of London-based Lehman Brothers Global Asset Management a decade later, has an eventual target of a more diversified, 50/50 split between institutional and retail accounts. Toward that end normally press-shy Legg Mason has kicked off a $4 million ad campaign that included Western's brand.   Among the fixed-income opportunities Western research has unearthed are some in U.S. autos and auto finance, involving General Motors (GM), Ford Motor (F), GMAC and Ford Motor Credit. Talk of their "imminent demise was overdone," says Leech. Problems -- especially legacy costs, or the big health-care and pension benefits awarded workers during the boom times before Japanese cars became the rage -- will be "worked out over a long period of time," he says.  These were the best performing corporate bonds in 2006.   Western is generally cautious on corporate bonds, however, "because risk premiums are so low" compared with their historical levels, cautions Leech. When Western managers do select a bond from that sector, they look for intermediate-term maturities in the three- to five-year range, says Stephen Walsh, Western's deputy chief investment officer, who has worked at the firm with Leech since the early 1990s.   The Western crew is known for being opportunistic in the mortgage market. "During the recent back-up" in prices caused by the subprime-mortgage mess, they added to their mortgage holdings --  though they buy only securities with top grades from the credit-rating agencies, says Walsh. Their favorites are government- and federal-agency guaranteed loans tracked by the Lehman Brothers U.S. Aggregate Index, including paper from Ginnie Mae, Fannie Mae (FNM) and Freddie Mac (FRE).   "Stable rates are good for mortgages . . . and prepay risk is low," says Leech, referring to the possibility a borrower will refinance at a lower yield, resulting in a corresponding discount in a mortgage investor's portfolio.   Although it isn't a slave to its macro view, Western expects moderate growth and inflation in the U.S. economy and "not a lot of meaningful change in rates," says Walsh. Western believes commodity prices in general and energy prices in particular have plateaued, easing inflation fears.   The firm's opportunistic bent isn't restricted to the U.S. and building its overseas holdings to roughly 50% from about 30% is another long-term goal. Western positioned itself in front of the United Kingdom's move last week to tighten monetary policy. It bought shorter-dated gilts on the belief that this rate hike will be the last, even though the market has braced for more.   Further afield, Western favors emerging markets like India, China, broadly Asia, Russia and the local currency bonds of Brazil. "We have to be very comfortable with the global economy and local politics" to buy, says Leech, citing improvement in Brazil's reserves and economic growth as key catalysts for raising exposure there.   Says Michael Larson, the chief investment officer of the $30 billion-plus Gates foundation, which handles investments for the philanthropic trust of Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates and his wife Melinda: "They're a very smart group of people who don't take a lot of risk and hit a lot of singles. They have a great track record . . . and low turnover."   And they're growing at a pretty good clip, too.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Turkey To Sell 20-Yr Oper Rights To Sabiha Gokcen Airport-IHA
Story: ISTANBUL (Dow Jones)--Turkey's Undersecretariat for Defense Industries, or SSM, will hold a tender July 9 to sell 20-year operating rights for Istanbul Sabiha Gokcen Airport, the Ihlas News Agency, or IHA, reported Saturday, citing the SSM's official Web site.   The winning investor will also build a new international flights terminal and complementary facilities to increase the airport's annual passenger capacity to 10 million from the current 3.5 million.   Seven consortiums are expected to submit bids in the tender.   The following consortiums have purchased tender documents and are expected to participate: Cukurova-Venedik-Vienna consortium, Malaysian Kuala Lumpur-Limak consortium, American ATMG-Makyol consortium, Esas Holding-TAV Havalimanlari Holding (TAVHL.IS) consortium, German Fraport (FRA.XE)-IC Holding consortium, Celebi Hava Servisi (CLEBI.IS)-Sheremetyevo International Airport consortium, Chinese Haikou Meilan International Airport-YDA Insaat consortium.     Agency Web sites: http://www.ihavideo.net and http://www.iha.com.tr     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 11:22 ET (15:22 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(7/9) Follow-Up: Carlyle Pays Up For Manor Care
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Robin Goldwyn Blumenthal   There is an upside to aging, at least for some longer-term investors in Manor Care.   In a widely anticipated transaction, the nursing-home company last week agreed to be taken private by Carlyle Group for $67 a share, or $6.3 billion, including debt. It had said in April that it was exploring strategic alternatives, and had received multiple bids before accepting Carlyle's, rendering a higher offer unlikely.   Though speculators and disappointed options traders who were looking for an offer closer to $70 a share pushed the shares 5% below the bid when the deal was announced, Carlyle's offer represents a tidy 32% gain from where the stock stood when Barron's penned a positive piece on the company early this year ("Lords of the Manor," Jan. 22). That compares with a 6% gain in the S&P 500 index over the same stretch.   We argued that investors weren't adequately rewarding Manor Care, which owns most of its 500 facilities, for the value of its substantial real-estate holdings and had underestimated the positive impact of its push into the higher-margin, shorter-stay rehabilitation market. In addition, Manor Care (ticker: HCR) counts higher-paying Medicare and private patients at a healthy 73% of its revenue mix.   The $67 cash offer values the company, which is expected to earn $2.79 a share this year on revenue around $3.9 billion, at a 20% premium to its peers, based on the price recently accepted by rival Genesis HealthCare from private-equity buyers. That's understandable because Manor Care "has always been the premier flagship name in the long-term care sector," says Frank Morgan, a Jefferies analyst.   Jim Lane, a portfolio manager at TriPoint Asset Management who had an 18-month target of $65 on Manor Care's shares in January, and has since pocketed a 30% gain on his position, pronounced the deal "very fair."   He noted that the offer values the company at $125,000 to $150,000 per bed, its replacement cost to build a new facility in a market where virtually no new building is taking place; Lane says that the bid for Genesis valued it at about $110,000 per bed.   Though there remain only two other pure-play publicly traded nursing home operators, it's doubtful that either will receive buyout bids anytime soon. Skilled Healthcare Group (SKH) just came public in May, and Sun Healthcare Group (SUNH) is digesting its acquisition of Harborside Healthcare, which should help it expand margins by a third, says Michael Wiederhorn, of CIBC World Markets.   Lane picked up Sun Healthcare, which recently has been changing hands at 15 and change, at about 13.50 a share.   Based on its current price, the stock trades at just $45,000 a bed, a figure he contends is a bargain. If Sun were to trade up to $65,000 per bed -- about half of the low end of Manor Care's per-bed cost -- that would represent a 30% gain, meaning that the stock would move up to about 20.   That would be a nice new wrinkle.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) The Trader: Buyouts Scatter Clouds Over Markets
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   Let's begin with the bad news.   Crude-oil prices climbed for the fourth straight week to a 10-month high of $72.81, up 44% since mid-January. The Bank of England raised rates for the fifth time in less than a year to try to quell inflation. In the U.S., Friday's robust jobs report and bond market selling pushed the 10-year Treasury yield near 5.20% from 5.03% a week earlier.   But into such gloom swoops a familiar figure. It's not a bird. It's not a plane. It's yetanother buyout firm!   While most Americans busied themselves with midsummer pleasures last week, private-equity buyers continued to browse for big multi-billion targets like Bell Canada Enterprises (ticker: BCE), Hilton Hotels (HLT) and Huntsman (HUN). Just when you thought they've all left for Lake Como, more than $45 billion worth of U.S. buyouts were announced by Friday. That accounted for 74% of all mergers last week, says Thomson Financial, producing private equity's second busiest week of 2007.   The debt market also stayed open for business. With minor tweaks, bond offerings to finance big buyouts -- like that of Dollar General (DG) -- got done, much to the relief of those watching for the onset of buyers' remorse.   Private equity's very public buying helped assuage -- at least for now -- the fears about waning liquidity and constricting credit. That, along with relative calm on the hedge-fund front, lifted the major benchmarks toward the top of their recent trading range. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 203, or 1.5%, to 13,612, while the Standard & Poor's 500 index climbed 27, or 1.8%, to 1530. Both have risen in three of the past four weeks.   But technology and small stocks racked up even bigger gains amid evidence of resurgent economic growth. The Nasdaq Composite Index rallied 63, or 2.4%, to 2667, its highest finish since Feb. 1, 2001. The Russell 2000 Index of small stocks added 19, or 2.2%, to 852.   Without giving too much credence to a few quiet sessions, last week's drift suggests, at the very least, that stocks' path of least resistance remains upward. The percentage of New York Stock Exchange stocks above their 200-day moving averages hovers near a rather neutral 61%, well off February's overwrought -- and overbought -- high of 86%.   The S&P 500 has hovered within a tight 3.5% range for more than two months, and bulls see that as a necessary "consolidation" before the next surge. But the direction of this liquidity-driven stock market continues to depend largely on debt-market cues, and bears brushed aside this latest flurry of private-equity deals as a dash to beat rising borrowing costs.   Economic data remain cooperative and point to a gradual reacceleration of growth. Manufacturing activity increased for the third straight month, and employers added 132,000 jobs in June and kept the unemployment rate at 4.5%. Worries of growth overheating were kept in check by the continued housing rot, and a consensus that growth could moderate once the recent push to replenish inventory is complete.   As the roster of stocks trading near their 52-week highs thins, it has gotten conspicuously crowded with big tech bellwethers: Apple (AAPL), Dell (DELL), Intel (INTC), International Business Machines (IBM), Hewlett Packard (HPQ), Texas Instruments (TXN) and Google (GOOG). And while stock benchmarks struggled, the Nasdaq has persistently pushed to fresh 6 1/2-year highs.   This recent affinity for the tech sector could be a bullish longer-term omen for the overall stock market, notes technical analyst Katie Townshend of MKM Partners, "particularly because it is occurring at the expense of more defensive sectors such as pharmaceuticals and consumer staples."   Several factors drive this renewed appetite, and explain why the time might be right to bet on big tech. The sector comes under both "growth" and "cyclical" labels, and will draw attention should economic expansion pick up as expected. And currently serving the seventh year of a long sentence for their complicity in the 2000 bubble, tech stocks continue to be shunned by a big swath of the investing public. All this augurs well for potential upside as skepticism dissipates.   Even as the economic recovery unfolded, the long-predicted ramp-up in capital spending remains missing in action. "When it ultimately does occur, tech will likely be the biggest beneficiary," says James Paulsen, Wells Capital Management's chief investment strategist.   Current economic growth also is spearheaded by overseas markets less saturated with technology, compared with developed economies. "A lot of tech spending could come simply from these new emerging economies catching up," Paulsen says.   Valuation also remains reasonable when viewed against growth prospects. The median S&P 500 tech company is expected to produce long-term growth of 15%, compared with 12% for the S&P 500 median company. If Treasury yields behave, the ability of big techs -- particularly those with well-capitalized balance sheets -- to increase profits three times faster than long-term borrowing costs will continue to woo investors.   A June poll conducted by Deutsche Bank and CIO Magazine has chief information officers projecting a 7.2% rise in technology budgets over the next 12 months --  up from 5.1% in March. The quarterly survey of more than 2,000 CIOs flagged storage systems as their top spending priority, with 54% of respondents planning to increase spending (up from 46% in March). Next on their list: security software, followed by computer hardware.   Zsa Zsa Gabor, who was once Mrs. Conrad Hilton, said she "welcomed all men's advances as long as they are in cash." Last week, the hotel empire that Conrad founded welcomed an all-cash $26 billion offer to be taken private by the Blackstone Group (BX). And the market's reaction suggests it expects many more such advances to be made.   Hotel stocks across the world jumped as speculators declared open season on big hotel brands. Blackstone's 47.50-a-share bid pegs Hilton (HLT) at about 13.5 times 2008 Ebitda, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. Analysts applying that multiple to Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide (HOT), for example, arrived at a price of about 82, and shares promptly climbed 8% Thursday to 74.50. Even Marriott International (MAR), family-controlled and thought less susceptible to buyouts, saw its shares rise 7%. Host Hotels (HST) jumped 10%.   The headlong speculative dash aside, the notion that hotel stocks just might be undervalued -- which Barron's raised last year ("Golden Name, Platinum Properties," May 15, 2006) -- remains compelling.   For all their charms, hotel stocks still worry investors with their vulnerability to terrorism and economic risk. Measures of industry health like room prices, occupancy rates and "RevPAR," or revenue per available room, have improved steadily and for longer than many expected. But that has only increased concern about a peaking cycle, encouraging profit-taking. Meanwhile, supply growth continues to trail demand, especially in major cities and in markets where condo developers are snapping up prized hotels, and Blackstone's bid is a vote of confidence on this enduring cycle.   Susquehanna analyst Robert LaFleur has argued that hotels look like a risk-adjusted bargain, relative to other assets like office buildings, malls and apartments. "The bottom line is that there continues to be a big gap between private market and public market valuations," he notes.   Hotels make up 48% of the Alpine U.S. Real Estate Equity Fund (EUEYX), for instance, because its managers see them offering "still the best opportunity in the real-estate space," says Sam Lieber, president of Alpine Mutual Funds, which holds about 2.5 million Hilton shares.   Eventually, the clamor to meet the demand boom will produce a supply glut, but Lieber thinks the sector is two to five years from its peak -- even longer overseas. The U.S. leisure industry employs less than 10% of the workforce but has accounted for one out of every four new jobs created.   But not all hotels are created equal, as road warriors well know. Franchises mining the lower price points -- like Choice Hotels (CHH), with its Comfort Inns and Econo Lodges -- and those with a heavy domestic or suburban footprint could see growth slow well before their big, geographically expansive counterparts with strategic toeholds in crowded meccas.   "The big brands benefit most from the extended cycle not only because they have the best existing supply, but also because they're bringing on the kind of supply that can best generate longer-term growth," Lieber says. He favors Starwood, Marriott, Orient Express (OEH), and, on the international front, Banyan Tree Holdings (BTH.Singapore), Mandarin Oriental International (MAND.Singapore), Shangri-La Asia (69.Hong Kong) and Hong Kong & Shanghai Hotels (45.Hong Kong).   Virgin Media shares (VMED) have rallied 21% since our May 14 column singled out the U.K. cable giant as undervalued and ripe for a buyout. Last week, the company confirmed it has been approached by a suitor it would not identify, and which reportedly is the Carlyle Group.   Although an offer could value Virgin's equity at $8 billion to $10 billion, or 30 to 35 a share, its Nasdaq-listed shares were trading recently at just about 29.31, with the discount reflecting the not-yet-definite offer.   Virgin has failed to consummate a deal with private-equity wooers before (most recently last summer), but the urgency mounts with each passing year. After paying up to buy rival Telewest and Virgin Mobile, the former NTL still hasn't fully maximized its allure as the U.K.'s only "quad" play of television, broadband, fixed-line and mobile-phone services.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) The Trader: Buyouts Scatter Clouds -2-
Story: Shareholder churn has swelled investor ranks with impatient fund managers. Franklin Mutual Advisers recently amassed a 9.4% stake and began prodding management for action. A $12 billion debt load also may not deter buyers, since Virgin generates enough  cash to cover loan payments. Carlyle is no stranger to cable deals, and Virgin's infrastructure  is unparalleled.   Increasingly, the market also seems to warm to the idea of Virgin as a private entity. "The things that are delaying its turnaround" -- from its programming spat with British Sky Broadcasting (BSY) to its struggle to price products -- "are all better tackled as a private concern out of the eye of the very aggressive British media and the scrutiny of sell-side analysts," says Brad Ruderman of Ruderman Capital Management. Headline: Barron's(7/9) Seeking Value In Brics -2-
Story: But some investors are already ahead of the pack, leaving the BRIC concept behind and looking for new ways to slice and dice the once-monolithic emerging- markets universe. "Given the giant divergence in per- capital GDP -- from a few hundred dollars up to the $18,000 range for Korea and Taiwan -- within the emerging-markets category, and even on a regional basis, this search for themes seems logical and convenient," says JPMorgan's Iwanicki. "There is a willingness on the part of investors to look over the horizon and look for another subset of the emerging-markets universe that has the potential to give them the kind of ride they have experienced first in Southeast Asia and now in BRICs."   Investment management firms are already devising new concepts. Goldman Sachs itself has identified a grouping of 11 markets that it sees as on the point of emerging into the mainstream. But this group -- dubbed the N-11, or next 11 -- may be too heterogeneous to be viewed as one investable universe.   "It's a very disparate group of countries, mixing new frontier markets like Vietnam with more developed ones like Korea," notes Deseglise. (The N-11 grouping also includes Iran, making the theme politically tricky for American investors.) He and others argue that to be a valid concept on which to base new fund vehicles, the countries grouped together would need to demonstrate the same kind of diversity in their economies but similar characteristics with respect to economic growth and lack of correlation with the broader investment universe.   Some European money managers believe they have found the right kind of offering: the so-called frontier funds. London-based Progressive Asset Management last month launched an investment fund on London's AIM market. Called the Advance Frontier Markets Fund, it will invest in countries ranging from Vietnam to the war-torn Ivory Coast, and can be purchased by U.S. investors. Other potential candidates for this kind of frontier fund could include Colombia or Peru in Latin America, Nigeria in Africa and Kazakhstan in Central Asia. Even Saudi Arabia, if it decides to open its markets to foreigners, might be an interesting candidate.   Frontier markets wouldn't have the same gut appeal that BRIC offers, however: While the rationale may be compelling, a frontier fund would need to include far more countries, none of which would ever match BRIC nations in scale. "It remains to be seen what the next step in this evolution is -- whether it's frontier funds or something else, like dedicated emerging-markets hedge funds," says Iwanicki. "The only certainty is that the market has finally recognized that not all emerging markets are created equal."   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:10 ET (04:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) Barron's Online: Adding Some Fizz To Liz: Liz Claiborne Gets Set For A Turnaround; Why Insiders Are Loading Up On The Shares
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Johanna Bennett   While fashionistas mourn the passing of iconic clothing-designer Liz Claiborne, the beleaguered company bearing her name is tailoring a smart turnaround.   Hurt by unexpectedly falling sales and earnings, its stock (ticker: LIZ) dropped 28% from a record-high in February to a 52-week low in May, according to Thomson Financial.   But at an investor meeting slated for next week, management may unveil sweeping and profitable changes at Liz Claiborne, including cost cuts and big divestitures.   Before the confab, insiders and big shareholders are buying the stock in anticipation of profits getting back on a growth track. In May, Aim Trimark Investments and Lazard Asset Management -- two of Liz Claiborne's biggest shareholders -- added significantly to their holdings. And on May 3, director Paul Tierney made the biggest insider purchase of Liz Claiborne stock in four years -- 30,000 shares for $1.1 million.   Founded in 1976 by Claiborne (then a relatively unknown dress designer), her husband and two partners, the company made history by introducing American working women to stylish clothes at affordable prices. Claiborne died last month at age 78.   The company last year generated sales of almost $5 billion, selling men's and women's clothing, accessories, jewelry and shoes under the flagship Liz Claiborne label, as well as Ellen Tracy and Dana Buchman.   Sales to big retailers such as Macy's, Liz Claiborne's biggest customer, generated 72% of company revenue.   Under previous Chief Executive Officer Paul Charron, the company tried to lessen its dependence on department stores and its Liz Claiborne label by opening company-owned stores and building a portfolio of more than 40 brands that includes Juicy Couture, Lucky brand Jeans, and handbag designer Kate Spade.   "They have been in a big acquisition mode since 1990, and retail has been a big initiative over the last four years," says Kate McShane, an analyst with Citigroup Global Markets.   Current CEO William McComb, a former Johnson & Johnson executive with a reputation for improving brand names, took over in November. (The company declined to make McComb available for an interview.)   But the Liz Claiborne label, once a mainstay in department stores, has lost popularity and sales. Plus, retailers like Federated are buying less from wholesale vendors, pushing instead higher-margin in-house brands.   Liz Claiborne's first-quarter profits fell 65%. And the company said fall orders are substantially below expectations, causing a drop in profits this year.   Liz Claiborne now pegs 2007 earnings at $1.90 a share to $2.05 a share. According to Thomson Financial, analysts' consensus EPS estimates plunged to $2.06 from a previous estimate for $3.12 a share. The new lower analyst estimate would mean earnings would fall 31% from 2006.   McComb is expanding on a restructuring plan that began in 2005. He has cut some underperforming businesses, hired a new chief financial officer and earlier this year brought on Tim Gunn, an adviser on the Project Runway television show, as chief creative officer to juice up the Liz Claiborne brand.   And last month, management restructured Liz Claiborne for the second time since 2005, splitting the company into two divisions, one for fast-growing labels sold through company-owned stores, and another on brands sold predominantly through department stores.   Now all eyes rest on the investor meeting on July 11.   McComb has been cryptic, says Citigroup's McShane. But analysts have pieced together expectations from his past statements.   Omar Saad, an analyst with Credit Suisse, says Liz Claiborne will sell, license out or discontinue many of its brands, though not its Liz Claiborne label.   The fast-growing Juicy, Kate Spade, Lucky and Mexx labels will become the company's growth drivers, or "power brands." The divestitures should free up resources to invest elsewhere, and cost cuts could help margins, says McShane.   Over the next three years, margins could double, Saad says, resulting in profits of $3.50 a share by 2010, up 17% from last year.   On the surface, Liz Claiborne shares look a little pricey at 18.2 times estimated 2007 earnings.   Yet the shares trade at a just 15.3 times the improved earnings expected for 2008. Plus, its price-to-sales and price-to-cash flow multiples also look cheap.   Meanwhile, Credit Suisse's Saad expects the stock to hit 45 a share in the next year, a 20% upside to today's close.   Of course, Liz Claiborne's financial challenges will persist this year. Much about the restructuring remains uncertain.   Some other hurdles: Competition among apparel makers is fierce, McComb is relatively untried as chief executive, and the unexpected loss of President Trudy Sullivan, who is departing to take over as chief executive at women's clothing retailer Talbot's   "There is a lot of optimism that the analyst meeting will open up a whole new chapter for Liz Claiborne," says Brad Stephens, an analyst with Morgan Keegan. "There is still a lot of heavy lifting."   Still, the company appears to be taking the right steps to weather industry-wide troubles and reinvigorate profits. And investors willing to give Liz Claiborne time to finish its alterations may enjoy the fit.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: KBR, Algeria State Oil Company Sign $2.88 Bln LNG Plant Deal
Story: ALGIERS (AP)--Algeria's state oil and gas company and KBR Inc. (KBR) signed a $2.88 billion deal Saturday for a liquefied natural gas plant.   The Skikda plant, on Algeria's eastern Mediterranean coast, will be the country's largest LNG facility, with a capacity of 4.5 million tons of liquefied gas per year, according to state-run Sonatrach. It will be on the site of a Sonatrach refinery wrecked by a gas tank explosion in 2004 that killed 27 people.   Work on the new plant begins in September, and it is scheduled to start production in 2011. The gas will come from the Hassi R'Mel field in the Sahara Desert in southern Algeria, according to the deal.   John Rose, executive vice president of KBR, and Abdelhafid Feghouil, vice president of Sonatrach, signed the contract in Algiers in the presence of Energy Minister Chakib Khelil.   Khelil expressed hope that the plant would allow Algeria to boost its production capacity and its sales to lucrative European markets.   Algeria, a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, is one of the world's largest exporters of natural gas and derives most of its income from the sale of hydrocarbons.   Houston-based KBR, formerly known as Kellogg, Brown & Root, is a military contractor and engineering and construction company that split from Halliburton Co. (HAL) in April. KBR and Halliburton have drawn criticism because of KBR's Pentagon contracts to be the sole provider of food and shelter services to the military in Iraq and Afghanistan. Democrats in Congress have claimed KBR benefited from ties to U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney, who once led Halliburton.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 14:35 ET (18:35 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) Seeking Value In Brics
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Suzanne McGee   Two decades after Mark Mobius began preaching the attractions of emerging markets, investment in them is taking its next big leap forward. "Emerging markets then was a kind of amorphous concept, and nobody cared one way or another about the differences between the individual countries that made up the category," Mobius, a Franklin Templeton director, recalls. Today, that's different. "Now investors are more sophisticated and knowledgeable about the asset class, and they are looking for ways to move onto the next stage of emerging- markets investing."   Indeed, the differences among countries and regions are now being deemed more important than their similarities. And many markets seem to be caught in some kind of no man's land, no longer merely "emerging" but still not quite worthy of the label of "developed."   In Central Europe, for instance, countries such as Hungary and Romania -- former satellites of the now-defunct Soviet Union and now members of the European Union -- offer a way to bet on the convergence of historically weak economies with those of more developed EU members, such as Germany and the United Kingdom.   At the same time, some nations that were definitely in the emerging stage a quarter-century ago have made huge strides on the global economic stage. "Some people question what countries like Korea or Taiwan are doing at all in the family of emerging markets today," says Maria Gordon, co-head of global emerging-markets equities for Goldman Sachs Asset Management in London.   At the other extreme are countries such as Nigeria and Vietnam, whose markets are still so underdeveloped that they make investing in the Thai market of two decades ago look positively simple in comparison.   Then there's the current sweet spot of the emerging-markets universe: Brazil, Russia, India and China: the "BRIC" markets.   The acronym was coined in 2001 by Jim O'Neill, head of global economic research at Goldman Sachs, to describe the group of giant economies that he believed would overtake the developed markets in size and importance by the middle of the 21st century.   Not surprisingly, investment firms around the world jumped aboard the BRIC bandwagon. EPFR Global, a Cambridge, Mass-based research firm, estimates that more than $13 billion is invested in the two dozen or so BRIC funds that have been launched in financial centers ranging from London and Luxembourg to Hong Kong and New York. Lately, however, investors' enthusiasm for these funds has waned.   "From mid-2005, when we first started tracking these funds, investor zeal was unstoppable right up until the end of last year," says Brad Durham, a managing director of EPFR, who tracks fund flows into global BRIC funds. "Then people hit the pause button and started pulling money out."   But the BRIC phenomenon appears to be far from over. After 11 straight weeks of net outflows, investors put money back into BRIC funds in the week ended June 27, the latest period for which data are available. Meanwhile, HSBC Asset Management is forging ahead with plans to introduce one of its two offshore BRIC funds to U.S. investors this fall. The BRIC Markets Fund, based on a quantitative model that screens stocks in the four markets for a variety of growth characteristics, will join funds launched by Goldman Sachs and Franklin Templeton in June 2006 and that means that three of these funds will be available to U.S. retail investors. "This is a 50-year theme, and we are still just at the start of that," says Gordon, who co-manages the Goldman Sachs BRIC fund (ticker: GBRAX).   Investors' love affair with Chinese stocks is quite apparent. Through the middle of last week, the Shanghai Composite index was up 39% this year. But stocks in Russia and Brazil haven't fully benefited from the theme as yet, Gordon notes. Although Brazil's Bovespa index is ahead 24.5% in 2007, Gordon adds, "the BRIC thesis has been least realized there; we are still waiting for the fruition of policy initiatives to allow the country to grow much faster than it has in prior years."   According to their advocates, BRIC funds give investors exposure to the best of what emerging markets promise: outsize economic expansion, improving financial- market liquidity and above-average growth in corporate earnings and profits. "The idea is that these four countries, taken together, offer the investor the best of what they are looking for when they decide to go into the emerging-markets asset class in the first place," says George Iwanicki, macro strategist for global emerging markets at JPMorgan Asset Management. "These are by far the largest, the most dynamic, the most liquid of the emerging markets."   In a report published in mid-June, Standard & Poor's analyst Srikant Dash spelled out the rationale behind that assertion. He noted that investors who put money into a broader emerging-markets fund usually find themselves in a portfolio that uses the MSCI Emerging Market index as a benchmark. The problem? That index is dominated by what Dash dubs the "advanced" emerging markets -- Korea, Taiwan, Mexico and South Africa etc. -- that were among the first to break out and grab investors' attention in the 1990s. Those markets now make up 44% of the MSCI index, thanks to the rapid strides they have made in liquidity, plus their success in attracting investment capital at home and abroad, but represent only 5% of global gross domestic product.   In contrast, Dash notes, the BRIC countries represent 27% of global GDP, but a relatively measly 37% of the MSCI index. As BRIC markets become more liquid and transparent, their importance will grow to match that of the four nations' economies. That in turn suggests potentially strong growth in the stock markets of Brazil, Russia, India and China.   BRIC fans suggest that the investment theme stretches well beyond the conventional emerging-markets analysis, however. While other emerging markets end up absorbed into one regional trading bloc or another, as Turkey is doing with the European Union and Mexico has already done with the United States, the BRICs aren't likely to emerge as anyone's satellite. "These four countries are in a different league; they are the only countries in the emerging-markets world with the potential to become centers of development in their own right and follow the lead of the U.S., the EU or Japan," says Christian Deseglise, global head of the emerging-markets business for HSBC Capital Management in New York. "This acronym is far from being a marketing gimmick, as some have suggested."   That doesn't mean that the BRIC road will be free of bumps. Investors have already tasted the volatility that accompanies torrid growth and high market returns: Twice this year, the Chinese stock market has plunged 10% or so in a single day. (That market took another big hit last week, dropping by 5%.) And memories are still vivid of how the emerging-markets boom of the 1990s turned sour in 1997 and 1998.   Even BRIC fans like Goldman's Gordon agree that it isn't different this time. "There will be volatility," she says. Gordon hails her fund's one-year return of 44.83%, through May 31, before sales charges. (The competing Templeton BRIC Fund [TABRX] is up 49.59% in the year through June 30, before sales charges.) But she hastens to add that "this isn't a story about five-year returns, but about what happens over decades. It's quite a long-term call."   Still, Gordon and her peers believe that blending the best of what the four stock markets have to offer will provide a built-in buffer, given the big differences between the markets. For instance, while Brazil and Russia are both big commodity producers, Russia's markets are geared more to metals and energy, while Brazil is a powerhouse agricultural commodity producer.   Meanwhile, China and India both offer plays on the desire of a growing middle class to boost savings and consumption. But the two countries' demographics differ sharply. "If you put all these together, you create a portfolio that has more equilibrium and less vulnerability to external shocks," argues Deseglise.   For Gordon, part of the process of designing her firm's BRIC fund was the creation of a customized index that reflects not just the current economic makeup of the four markets but incorporates its future growth trajectory. "We chose to change our benchmark to include less oil and fewer mining stocks than the market capitalization of these markets suggested," she says. "We're not interested in just blindly following what is available to buy. At any point in time, we are looking for where we see the best value in this 50-year theme."   These days, that means underweighting China, which makes up nearly a third of the GSAM index but as of March 31 (the latest available data) only 28.2% of the fund's holdings. Instead, the fund maintains a slightly overweight position in Russian stocks, which make up nearly 24% of assets.   "That is where we are finding stocks that are not priced for perfection," Gordon says. Currently, these include coal producer Raspadskaya; Uralkaliy, a potash company, and Sberbank, a bank that offers exposure to the evolution of the country's domestic banking and lending infrastructure.   If ever Gordon and her fellow BRIC managers feel there aren't enough opportunities in the BRIC countries themselves, they are free to follow BRIC-related themes and invest up to 20% of the fund's assets in companies based in other nations that tie into the concept. "For instance, part of the BRIC story is the insatiable demand for natural resources, so Canadian, Australian or Latin American names could qualify for inclusion on that basis," Gordon explains.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Hershey(R)'S Kisses(R) Brand Chocolates Celebrates Centennial Birthday
Story: World's Largest Hershey(R)'s Kisses(R) Chocolate" Inducted into Guinness World Records(TM)       HERSHEY, Pa., July 7 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- The iconic Hershey(R)'s Kisses(R) Brand Chocolates commemorated its 100th anniversary today with a record-breaking celebration in Hershey, Pa. The Hershey Company celebrated the brand's centennial by unveiling "The World's Largest Hershey's Kisses Chocolate" at a birthday event hosted at Hershey's Chocolate World(R) Attraction in Hershey, Pa., The Sweetest Place on Earth(R). Complete with a seven-foot-long plume and 16,460-feet of foil wrapping, The World's Largest Hershey's Kisses Chocolate weighed in at 30,540 pounds and was certified by Guinness World Records(R) as "The World's Largest Piece of Chocolate."        (Photo: http://www.newscom.com/cgi-bin/prnh/20070707/CLSA005)     "Hershey's Kisses Chocolates is one of the world's most beloved brands, helping people connect and share affection for 100 years," said Michele Buck, Senior Vice President, Chief Marketing Officer, U.S., The Hershey Company. "Our tribute honors the iconic brand and continues the magic of our yearlong Kiss Someone(TM) celebration. What a great way to start the next 100 years of Hershey's Kisses."     The World's Largest Hershey's Kisses Chocolate took nine days to construct and stands 12-feet tall. Consumers can see the making of the commemorative Hershey's Kisses Chocolate by logging on to www.kisssomeone.com or by visiting Hershey's Chocolate World Attraction through July 12, 2007.     Hershey's Kisses Chocolates were first introduced on July 7, 1907, at a time when each chocolate piece was wrapped by hand. While the milk chocolate flavor has been an American favorite for 100 years, today the Hershey's Kisses Brand line features a variety of flavors including: Hershey's Kisses with almonds, Hershey's Kisses filled with caramel, Hershey's Kisses Special Dark chocolate, Hershey's Kisses chocolate truffle, Hershey's Kisses filled with peanut butter, Hershey's Kisses filled with cherry cordial creme, Hershey's Hugs and Hershey's Mini Kisses Cookies. Hershey's Kisses also are available in Limited-Edition varieties throughout the year.     Visit www.hersheyskisses.com for more information on the Kiss Someone celebration and consumer promotion offering consumers the chance to win a share of $100 million.        About The Hershey Company     The Hershey Company (NYSE: HSY) is the largest North American manufacturer of quality chocolate and sugar confectionery products. With revenues of nearly $5 billion and more than 13,000 employees worldwide, The Hershey Company markets such iconic brands as Hershey's, Reese's, Hershey's Kisses, and Ice Breakers. Hershey is the leader in the fast-growing dark and premium chocolate segment, with such brands as Hershey's Special Dark, Hershey's Extra Dark and Cacao Reserve by Hershey's. Hershey's Ice Breakers franchise delivers refreshment across a variety of mint and gum flavors and formats. In addition, Hershey leverages its iconic brands, marketplace scale and confectionery and nut expertise to develop and deliver substantial snacks, including Hershey's and Reese's single-serve cookies and brownies, and value-added snack nuts, including Hershey's Milk Chocolate Covered Almonds and Hershey's Special Dark Chocolate Covered Almonds. Hershey also offers a range of products to address the health and well-being needs of today's consumer. Hershey's and Reese's Snacksters offer consumers great-tasting snacks in portion-controlled servings, while Hershey's dark chocolate offerings provide the benefits of flavanol antioxidants. In addition, Artisan Confections Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of The Hershey Company, markets such premium chocolate offerings as Scharffen Berger, known for its high-cacao dark chocolate products, Joseph Schmidt, recognized for its fine, handcrafted chocolate gifts, and Dagoba, known for its high-quality natural and organic chocolate bars. Visit us at www.hersheynewsroom.com.    SOURCE  The Hershey Company       /CONTACT: Cheryl Georgas, +1-630-932-7914, cheryl@jsha.com, or Jennifer Nau, +1-630-932-7987, jennifern@jsha.com, both of JSH&A Public Relations for The Hershey Company      /Web site: http://www.hersheyskisses.com      /Web site: http://www.kisssomeone.com      /Web site: http://www.hersheynewsroom.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 14:37 ET (18:37 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(7/9) 13D Filings: Investors Report To The SEC
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining more than 5% of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from June 28 through July 4.   Source: Dow Jones Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     American Community Properties (APO)   Investor Robert L. Chapman Jr. reiterated his demand that American Community double its 10 cents-a-share quarterly dividend. Chapman may consider various means to maximize shareholder value, including negotiated transactions, tender offers, proxy contests or other actions. Chapman currently holds 395,302 shares (7.6% of the total outstanding).     Wendy's International (WEN)   Triarc Cos. (TRY) has notified Wendy's that it considers itself "a natural, strategic buyer" of the hamburger chain, but contends that Wendy's is seeking to block any transaction. Triarc says it had been invited to participate in Wendy's potential sale process, but that the confidentiality agreement it received from an investment banker has a "restrictive one-year standstill clause to which Triarc has objected." Triarc's non-executive chairman, billionaire Nelson Peltz,  holds 8.55 million Wendy's shares (9.8%). He'd  been Triarc's CEO until resigning that post last week.     Bioenvision (BIVN)   SCO Capital Partners said that Genzyme's (GENZ) "failed" tender offer for Bioenvision proves that the $5.60-a-share bid was too low. SCO Capital says that the offer is well below UBS Securities' price target of $13. Genzyme is extending the offer until July 10 and waiving a condition that it acquire at least 50% of Bioenvision's outstanding common. SCO Capital Partners has 7,209,331 shares (13.4%).     Angelica (AGL)   Pirate Capital wants Angelica to take "immediate steps" to unlock shareholder value by retaining an investment bank to explore strategic alternatives, including a possible sale. Pirate Capital otherwise may nominate directors at the annual meeting. Pirate also wants to examine and copy some of the company's books, records and documents. Pirate Capital owns 935,147 shares (9.8%).     Kensey Nash (KNSY)   Admiral Advisors says the company's stock is significantly undervalued and wants Kensey Nash to focus on its core biomaterials business. Admiral Advisors believes that Kensey Nash could save up to $20 million a year by ending direct sales and significantly curbing research and development expenses for its endovascular line. The shareholder wants the board to consider a Dutch-auction tender offer to repurchase stock. Admiral Advisors owns 1,180,634 shares (9.9%).     Original Filings     Magna Entertainment (MECA)   Dorset Management has asked Magna to add an independent director to its board. Dorset owns 3,394,014 shares (6.9%).     Increases in Holdings     Orange 21 (ORNG)   Thesis Capital Management raised its holdings to 696,692 shares (8.6%) from the 611,799 (7.6%) reported in late May.     W.P. Stewart (WPL)   Van Den Berg Management boosted its stake to 11.6 million shares (24. 4%) from the 10.7 million (22.51%) reported on June 28.     Decreases in Holdings     Exco Resources (XCO)   Billionaire T. Boone Pickens owns 12.3 million shares (11.8%), after selling 159,500 on July 2 at an average $18.01 a share.     Openwave Systems (OPWV)   A group including Harbinger Capital Partners Master Fund I has 9.11 million shares (11%), after selling 2 million on June 25 and 26 at $6.25 to $6.58 apiece.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Possibly Tainted Toothpaste Found In Massachusetts Stores
Story: BOSTON (AP)--The concern about tainted toothpaste imported from China has spread to Massachusetts, where public health officials issued a consumer warning after suspect products were found in stores in nearly a dozen communities.   Officials urged consumers to avoid any toothpaste labeled "Made in China," any toothpaste labeled "Colgate" that is manufactured in South Africa and any toothpaste without English language labeling.   Last month, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration said toothpaste from China and counterfeit Colgate toothpaste may contain diethylene glycol, or DEG, a chemical used in antifreeze.   Massachusetts was not initially listed as a state where higher volumes of the product were found. But officials said Thursday that suspect products continue to be found, particularly in small, independent discount stores.   The state Department of Public Health said toothpaste with this suspect labeling has been found in Boston, Arlington, Dedham, Amherst, Malden, Lowell, Wellesley, West Springfield, Somerville, Lawrence and Sturbridge.   Neither the state nor the FDA is aware of any reports of poisonings from toothpaste containing DEG in Massachusetts or nationally, but health officials are concerned about potential risks from long-term use.   The bacteria could pose a significant health risk, especially to children and anyone with a weakened immune system.   The FDA and New York-based Colgate-Palmolive Co. (CL) have said the products are fake, citing in part misspellings on the packaging, such as "SOUTH AFRLCA." Its true origin is unknown, according to the FDA.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 10:01 ET (14:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Alstom Sees Being On Shortlist For EUR2B Italy Train Contract
Story: PARIS (Dow Jones)--Alstom SA (1022047.FR), the French power and transport group, believes it's one of two bidders shortlisted for a contract worth as much as EUR2 billion with Italian consortium NTV, the country's first private railway operator, for the supply of high-speed trains, Alstom executive vice-president Philippe Mellier said Saturday.   "We think we are one of the two bidders that have been shortlisted," Mellier said Saturday in an interview on the sidelines of a conference in Aix-en-Provence.   Alstom, which was known to have made a bid for the project, reached the final stage of the selection with German rival Siemens AG (SI), Mellier said.   If it wins the contract, due to be awarded in the coming weeks, Alstom will supply 25 high-speed trains, with an option for 10 more, Mellier said. The contract will include 30-year maintenance for the equipment, he said.   Mellier confirmed that Alstom won last month a $1.3 billion contract to build a 350-kilometer high-speed link to connect Argentina's capital Buenos Aires with the cities of Cordoba and Rosario.    -By Gabriele Parussini, Dow Jones Newswires; gabriele.parussini@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 07:29 ET (11:29 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) Tech Trader: Delivering Free Online Video -- And Mulling An Ipo
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Eric J. Savitz   With the rapid spread of video across the Internet, investors hankering for a way to play it find themselves with few direct options. YouTube was snapped up by Google (ticker: GOOG) long before it could have realistically attempted an IPO; other services are too new to even begin thinking about raising equity in the public markets.   But the first Web-video IPO could emerge in the next 12 months, from a company that at one point was almost synonymous with Internet video piracy: San Francisco-based BitTorrent.   BitTorrent really refers to three things: a company, a Website and a peer-to-peer file-sharing technology. Created by founder and CEO Bram Cohen, a reputedly brilliant but eccentric coder (the latest entry on his blog holds forth on why forks have only four tines), the BitTorrent software became a wildly popular way to search for video files. In 2004, a company called CacheLogic estimated that peer-to-peer file sharing then accounted for 60%-80% of overall Internet traffic, with BitTorrent accounting for about half of that. Some of the files traded via BitTorrent were legal; many others were not. The company contends it has cleaned up its act. But before we get to the details, let's step back a bit and look at the larger picture.   If you want to deliver videos or other large files over the Internet, you have several choices. The simple way is to just deliver them from a server in a single location, and it works reasonably well if you don't get a lot of traffic. A more sophisticated approach is to use a content-delivery network, like the ones operated by Akamai (AKAM) and the newly public Limelight Networks (LLNW). They store copies of files at various locations around the Internet, to make the delivery of content -- videos, music or images -- more efficient. BitTorrent and other peer-to-peer networks take the distribution of content one step further: Rather than pull content from servers, you grab it from other people who already have it -- from your peers. Part of the magic of BitTorrent's approach is that large files are broken into small pieces; a movie can show up not from a single location but from a variety of places, to be put back together again when it arrives on your PC.   In an effort to stay on the right side of the law, BitTorrent has gone out of its way to convince most of the major movie and television production companies that using peer-to-peer technology -- BitTorrent in particular -- will sharply cut the costs of delivering Web video.   In an interview with Barron's, BitTorrent President Ashwin Navin took the bold view that any company in the business of shipping popular video content around the Internet free will eventually decide that the economics require using peer-to-peer file distribution. For free content, Navin says, doing it any other way is almost impossible without losing money: "The numbers don't add up." Because of the technology required, he contends, a distributor can't generate enough dollars from advertising to provide consumers free high-quality video on the Internet using a centralized system or a content-delivery network.   Navin says mainstream content players offering free video content online tend either to reduce the quality of the content to shrink file sizes, or assume that eventually a flood of users will provide economies to shift the math.   But he says the math doesn't work for free content, even with a content-delivery network. He contends that ads on high-quality video content can be sold for a CPM, or cost per thousand, of $40-$50 for a short video ad; he figures consumers can tolerate maybe three of them in an hour-long free video program. That means $150 for 1,000 showings, which is 15 cents in revenue per user. Content-delivery costs wipe out that revenue and more right off the bat, he says. And by the way, he notes that the CPM that advertisers will pay for user-generated content runs as low as $1.   BitTorrent does seem to have done a pretty good job of persuading the major studios to work with them. Once feared in Hollywood, the company has cut distribution deals with MGM, 20th Century Fox, Lionsgate, Paramount and Warner Bros., among others. Navin says BitTorrent.com now offers more than 10,000 movies and television shows. A  quick perusal of the site finds available for rent or purchase mainstream movies like Borat, Babel, Blood Diamond, The Departed and An Inconvenient Truth; popular television shows like 24 and Buffy the Vampire Slayer; and a variety of free content, some of it user-generated, some of it older Hollywood material like the cult classic Night of the Living Dead and the 1934 version of Alfred Hitchcock's The Man Who Knew Too Much. In short, while you were thinking that BitTorrent was a creepy technology for trading illegal files, the company decided to take on Apple (AAPL), Amazon (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Wal-Mart (WMT) in downloadable video.   But there is more to BitTorrent than its Website. The key to the business is software. As Navin notes, the company has started shipping a developers' kit for something the company calls BitTorrent DNA, which provides a way for content developers to distribute content directly using the BitTorrent software. He notes that users have downloaded 160 million copies of the company's desktop software, with another 100,000 copies downloaded every day. He envisions BitTorrent becoming as ubiquitous -- and as non-threatening -- as Adobe's (ADBE) Flash player. The company has begun to license hardware manufacturers so they can include the software in media adapters and other devices that will connect the 'Net with your TV.   Investors on Sand Hill Road are betting that BitTorrent can figure out a way to make money here; the company has raised $30 million in venture capital from Accel Partners and Doll Capital Management. And Navin, a former Goldman Sachs banker, says an IPO "is certainly within the realm of possibility."   Speaking of video, a quick update. In my June 18 column, I asserted that cable companies were not going away, even with the proliferation of online video. One reason: Falling capital costs would lead to a big jump in cash flow. Last week, Craig Moffett at Bernstein Research noted that the recently filed proxy statement for the Dolan family's bid to take Cablevision Systems (CVC) private included a far more optimistic forecast for free cash flow than he or other analysts had been projecting. In short, Moffett thinks Cablevision is worth at least twice the $36 and change that the Dolans are offering, and he repeated his view that most companies in the sector are too cheap.   ---   E-mail: eric.savitz@barrons.com; blog: blogs.barrons.com   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) At The Center Of The Closed-End -2-
