Story: A: Managed payouts prescribe a fixed monthly or quarterly distribution rate or specify that distributions be based on a formula, such as a particular percentage of NAV, perhaps 8% or 10%. Before such high-payout policies were introduced, the way most closed-end funds made their payouts was to take the net income per share and distribute that in the form of a quarterly dividend or monthly dividend. For tax reasons, the funds also distributed to shareholders the realized long- and short-term capital gains, usually once a year. Now, that was confusing in itself, because for a typical equity fund, the net income per share is often only 1% or 2% or 3%. So if closed-end funds were just to pay out the net income per share, the investors would be getting a 2% to 3% yield in many cases.     Q: How do you define a closed-end fund's net income?   A: It is basically the interest and dividends the fund receives, minus the expenses to run the fund. Many of the data companies publish closed-end yields that include the capital-gains distributions, along with the dividends from net income per share. That is very misleading, because people would get, say, a distribution of which 2% or 3% was from net income. But up to 7% may be from capital gains or other sources, and they may think they're getting a 10% yield. The SEC and the funds have made significant efforts to clarify the composition of the distribution. But still, many investors confuse distributions with yield. Further complicating the matter is that some funds also supplement their payouts with return of capital.     Q: So what should investors be looking at?   A: Investors should read the disclosures accompanying their distributions very carefully. In some cases where the fund does not have enough net investment income and capital gains to make the prescribed payout, the fund may pay a return of capital. To the extent that the funds are paying out an amount in excess of their net income per share and/or capital gains, they are basically giving back shareholders their own money.     Q: A fund dipping into its own capital?   A: That's right; shareholders are getting their own money back. In other words, an investor may look at his brokerage statement or the yield on a quote machine or the yield in a newspaper and think he's getting 10%. But the real yield might be 2% or even less. Further complicating the matter is that many closed-end funds don't have an accurate breakdown of the source of the distribution until the year is over.     Q: We've seen more dissident activity in closed-ends. What's your take on that?   A: If you can buy a closed-end fund at a discount and force the management to convert it to an open-end fund or liquidate it, you would instantly make a windfall profit.     Q: Because it would convert at the fund's net asset value, right?   A: Yes. That strategy was adopted by many people who do takeovers, and there is an increasing number of takeovers and activists and raiders in the closed-end-fund world these days. Most of them are formed as hedge funds.     Q: Is that good, bad or in between?   A: It keeps the management of the closed-end funds very responsive to the shareholder valuation. We ourselves wouldn't take over a closed-end fund that we thought was well-managed just for the sake of liquidating it, nor would we support anyone else doing that.   We tend to support activists if they are trying to increase a fund's valuation. But the advantages of closed-end funds are that, although they may trade at discounts, there is nothing to prevent them from trading at premiums. Quite a number of closed-ends do trade at premiums these days. So if there could be measures put in place that would create an environment for the shares to trade at a premium, that's even better than liquidation or converting to an open-end fund.     Q: What are some closed-end funds you like?   A: I am buying some of the funds that don't have high-payout policies, because they are basically undervalued relative to the ones that have high-payout policies.     Q: How about a few names?   A: Some of the older funds, including Central Securities [CET]. We own one of the convertible-bond funds, Castle Convertible [CVF]. That was one of the first funds I ever bought. Castle has been trading at a persistent discount for a very long time, and the management really is long overdue to take some type of measure to narrow it. We also own Claymore/Raymond James SB-1 Equity [RYJ], which is interesting because it has a provision that if it trades at over a 10% discount starting at the end of this year for 75 consecutive trading days, it converts to an open-end fund.     Q: So these funds that you mentioned don't have high-payout policies, relative to some other funds?   A: That is true for all three. The Raymond James fund doesn't have a high-payout policy. It's at about a 10% discount to net asset value. If it starts trading at wider than a 10% discount continuously later this year, it's going to convert to an open-end fund. But that discount may well narrow. Adams Express [ADX] is another older fund that doesn't have a high-payout policy.     Q: What about some other themes?   A: We're looking at some foreign equity funds. The discounts have widened on a few of them. We recently bought some Templeton Dragon Fund [TDF], which is at about a 15% discount to its NAV.     Q: What are you steering clear of?   A: I am taking profits in funds that adopted high-payout policies. One of the risks is that if they don't earn the high payouts over an extended period, the assets will erode. Furthermore, I don't see any upside in the premium at this juncture, and they are vulnerable. As more and more funds adopt high-payout policies, there will be nothing special about funds paying out 8%-10%. The SEC has just instituted some policies requiring much stricter disclosure about how to present the yield. So once investors become more educated, share prices of the funds with high-payout policies will give ground and the money that comes out of those will go into the deeply discounted funds that don't have high-payout policies.     Q: What have you taken profits on?   A: We sold Tri-Continental [TY], which was our largest position. We did quite well with that one. They've just instituted a new payout policy. We also took profits on Neuberger Berman Realty Income [NRI], Neuberger Berman Real Estate Income [NRL] and Neuberger Berman Real Estate Securities Income [NRO]. NRI and NRO both recently announced 9% payout policies.     Q: What about bond funds?   A: With bond funds, it's almost always about discounts. We bought a number of the funds involved in the Legg Mason takeover of Citigroup's asset-management unit a few years ago. They were at very wide discounts and we loaded up, partly because we thought Legg Mason would do something meaningful about the discounts. We still own one or two, which are at wide discounts. Our holdings include Western Asset Emerging Markets Debt Fund [ESD], Western Asset Emerging Markets Income Fund II [EDF], and LMP Capital and Income [SCD].     Q: Any short positions you can talk about?   A: One is Eaton Vance Tax Managed Diversified Equity Income [ETY], which did an IPO last fall.     Q: It was the largest IPO ever for a closed-end fund. Why short it?   A: I sold short a number of these new issues. There are so many similar funds around that often are better values. It's not a bad hedge to be long some of the similar funds at wide discounts and short the new issues. I'm not picking on them. I have nothing against the management. It's just that the numbers work that way.     Q: Thanks very much, Tom.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK Rank Mulls Shifting Unit Overseas After Tax Hikes -Paper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Gaming company Rank Group PLC (RNK.LN) is considering moving its telephone and Internet sports betting businesses offshore in the wake of hefty tax rises imposed on gambling in the last U.K. budget, The Independent reported, citing Chief Executive Ian Burke.   Burke confirmed the company was considering moving its Blue Square betting operation offshore, which would enable it to avoid the 15% gross profits tax imposed on U.K.-based remote betting operations, the paper reports.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.independent.co.uk     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9413     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 07:43 ET (11:43 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Standard Life Cuts Unit Prices Of 5 Real Estate Funds -Paper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)-- New signs of turmoil in the U.K.'s shaky commercial property market have emerged after Standard Life PLC (SL.LN) slashed the unit prices of five of its real estate funds in response to nervous investors cashing in their holdings, The Daily Telegraph reported Saturday.   Standard Life said its funds would trade at the lower of the bid and offer prices at which unit trusts are valued, the newspaper said.   Fund management groups can move without warning from an offer price to a bid price if they are obliged to sell a fund's underlying investments to satisfy redemption, to protect investors who stay on board by passing on the costs of liquidating assets to those investors who are selling out, the newspaper said.   The affected funds are Property One, Pension Managed Property and Individual Property One pension funds and the Property Investment life funds, the newspaper reported.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.telegraph.co.uk     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9413     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 07:02 ET (11:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) The Sound Of Trouble
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Neil A. Martin   Sonosite, a leading maker of hand-carried ultrasound medical equipment, never used to see much of a threat in General Electric. After testing a rival product from GE last year, SonoSite CEO Kevin M. Goodwin said flatly, "We're not worried."   So much for bravado. GE Healthcare's compact LOGIQe, which takes direct aim at SonoSite's flagship MicroMaxx device, has enjoyed booming sales since its launch last May. GE's sales in the field, counting six other products itlaunched last year, have reached $174 million a year, eclipsing the sales of industry pioneer SonoSite and making GE the industry leader.   It's enough to make an investor think twice about SonoSite, and Barron's already has done that. Though bullish on the stock in the past ("SonoSite's Prognosis," Nov. 7, 2005), we are now wary because of the GE problem. The shares (ticker: SONO), down about 7% over the past year, to a recent 36, could well decline to about 30.   GE (ticker: GE) expects its sales of compact ultrasound machines to jump 50% this year, to $264 million, and to top $300 million in 2008, says Omar Ishrak, chief executive of GE's $4.5 billion-a-year-in-sales Healthcare Clinical Systems unit. His projection of 2008 sales would give GE some 58% of the expected global market of $510 million.   "So far, this market has grown at 30% to 50% a year over the past two or three years," Ishrak says. "We believe our share of this market will grow rapidly and may reach $500 million by 2010," he adds.   As if such plans weren't enough to hurt SonoSite, GE in May filed a lawsuit against SonoSite in a federal court in Wisconsin, alleging that SonoSite's MicroMaxx and another product infringe on five GE patents related to ultrasound technology. GE wants an injunction to prevent SonoSite from continuing to sell the products and seeks back royalties as part of an unspecified sum of money for damages.   "If the lawsuit is successful, it could be crippling to SonoSite, considering the company's one-dimensional product line," says Sean D. Lavin, a medical doctor and analyst with Oppenheimer & Co.   SonoSite not only denies it has infringed on GE patents, it also has filed a countersuit accusing GE of violating its patents. On the market-share front, SonoSite officials acknowledge they have has lost ground to GE in the past six months but claim they are making up for it in higher sales overseas and deeper inroads into hospitals and doctors' offices.   But GE, alas, isn't the only problem. SonoSite suffers from persistently high sales and marketing expenses, negative operating profit margins and flat-to-low gross profit margins (69.9%).   What's more, a recent sales and marketing reorganization proved disruptive. Though sales are expected to grow this year by 18%, to $202 million, that's far off the historical pace of 50% a year. There are also concerns that SonoSite is not spending enough on research to develop the new products needed to keep pace with GE.   You don't need an ultrasound test to see the problems behind this stock.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) Asian Trader: Activist Investing Advances Slowly In Japan
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jamie Miyazaki   Activist funds calling on Japanese companies to do more to maximize returns continue to be snubbed, after emerging from June's shareholder meetings with little to show for their efforts. But most are unlikely to give up their quest, given the need for change and the potential rewards.   Most demands for bigger dividends and the elimination of takeover-defense mechanisms were rejected by shareholders during meeting season. In keeping with that trend, Steel Partners Japan Strategic Fund revealed Thursday that its bid to acquire the outstanding shares of Tenryu Saw Manufacturing (ticker: 5945.Japan) had failed, as its tender offer garnered just 2.6% of the blade and cutlery manufacturer's stock.   Many overseas investors had hoped June would mark a watershed for Japanese corporate governance. New legislation making hostile takeovers easier had whetted their expectations that management would become more responsive to shareholder demands. But those hopes were stillborn after Japanese shareholders backed corporate managers in votes at annual meetings, dismissing the activists as opportunists bent on stripping cash from balance sheets. Comments like those of Steel Partners President Warren Lichtenstein, who said he would help "educate" Japanese management, also alienated local investors.   Also typical of the activists' defeat was a failed bid by the hedge fund Fursa Alternative Strategies to push heating-equipment maker Noritz (5943.Japan) to hike its dividend more than tenfold, to 300 yen from 28 yen . Fursa's proposed payout ratio of 450% struck many Japanese as excessive, notwithstanding Noritz's cash-rich balance sheet or the growth of the country's nascent dividend culture.   Corporate Japan has battened down the hatches. According to Nomura, cross-shareholdings, one of Japan Inc.'s old methods of warding off shareholders looking to upset the status quo, rose modestly in fiscal 2006. After sliding for 15 years, the cross-shareholding ratio, a measure of how much Japanese companies have invested in one another, relative to the market's total capitalization, ticked up 0.1 of a percentage point, to 11.2%. Company boards also have been rushing to embrace poison pills, or anti-takeover measures.   Yet, calls for Japanese executives to do more to boost shareholder returns are well-grounded, which has made this year's drubbing all the more depressing for those seeking to effect change. Japanese companies have the lowest return on equity -- 10.3%, on average -- among Asian, European and U.S. concerns, and the lowest dividend yield at 1.1%, according to Goldman Sachs.   Still, while overseas agitators may have lost this round, even the Pension Fund Association in Japan appears to be clambering onto the activist bandwagon; the organization has said it will vote against the re-election of board members at companies whose return on equity has been less than 8% in each of the past three years. The clock is unlikely to turn back to the mid-1990s, when returns on equity were hovering around 5%.   In addition, activist investors have notched a few notable successes. Sparx Group, a Japanese fund-management company, did some behind-the-scenes arm-twisting to pressure camera maker Pentax to agree to a 105 billion yen  tender offer from optical-glass maker Hoya (7741.Japan), after a board rebellion at Pentax initially had scuppered the deal.   Ichigo Asset Management, a small Japan-focused fund, marshaled enough support to strike down a proposed merger between Tokyo Kohtetsu (5448.Japan) and Osaka Steel (5449.Japan), arguing that the share-swap ratio shortchanged Tokyo Kohtetsu's investors. Crucially, Ichigo engaged individual Japanese investors to win support for its campaign. It also has taken a pragmatic approach to poison pills, by supporting Tokyo Kohtetsu's version at this year's shareholder meeting.   Companies grudgingly have become more responsive to investors' demands. Wig maker Aderans (8170.Japan) responded to Steel Partners' insistence that it shelve its poison pill by proposing a corporate value-improvement plan, while Ono Pharmaceutical (4528.Japan) answered requests from the mutual fund Brandes Investment Partners to hike its dividend sevenfold by tabling its payout policy, which had been based on the level of its free cash flow.   As much as it might rile Corporate Japan, the antics of activists seem to have unlocked value at companies in their crosshairs. An index created by Nikko Citigroup to track the approximate performance of a basket of activist funds has shown a 350% return from July 2002 to May 2007. The Topix, in contrast, has notched a 71% gain.   This alone suggests that the Steel Partners of the world won't give up. In light of the activists' returns, maybe they'll have more success, in the next round, by ensuring that Japan's corporate managers are rewarded with stock options.   ---   Jamie Miyazaki, who is based in Tokyo, is a reporter for Dow Jones Newswires.   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Volkswagen CEO: Co Mulls Building First US Factory -Report
Story: BERLIN (AP)--The chief executive of Volkswagen AG (VOW.XE) said in an interview released Saturday the German auto giant would consider building a factory in North America if the U.S. dollar remains weak against the euro.   Already VW is planning to set up a second administrative hub near Detroit, "to get closer to our customers" there, Martin Winterkorn told the German weekly Focus. VW confirmed the interview.   Volkswagen, based in Wolfsburg, Germany, already has a subsidiary, Volkswagen of America Inc., headquartered in Auburn Hills, Mich. Last week, Stefan Jacoby was named as president and CEO of Volkswagen of America.   Winterkorn said the company was also weighing the possibility of building its first factory in the U.S., where it hopes to improve sales of its vehicles and increase its share of the highly competitive market.   "If the dollar exchange rate stays at its present level, we will have to begin thinking about a factory in North America," Winterkorn said.   The dollar, which began to weaken broadly in early 2002, has fallen more than 50% from its October 2000 trading peak against the euro, which bought $1.3623 on Friday.   The company expects to set a new record for vehicle sales in 2007, pushing beyond the 6 million car mark, Winterkorn said, crediting increased productivity for the jump. In 2006 the company sold 5.7 million cars.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 08:55 ET (12:55 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Air One Plans EUR1.7 Bln Bid For Alitalia - Newspaper
Story: FLORENCE, Italy (Dow Jones)--Italy's second-largest carrier, Air One, plans to make a bid worth some EUR1.7 billion for Alitalia SpA (AZA.MI), with the financing coming entirely from five banks, an Italian daily reported Saturday.   The EUR1.7 billion would be split between EUR450 million in equity of Air One's parent company, AP Holding, and EUR1.25 billion in loans that Air One would use to purchase Italy's biggest airline, Rome daily Il Messagero said. Alitalia's current market capitalization is around EUR1.1 billion.   The financing would be split among five banks: Italian banks Intesa Sanpaolo SpA (ISNPY) and Monte dei Paschi di Siena; and foreign banks Lehman Brothers, Morgan Stanley (MS), and Nomura.   Intesa Sanpaolo is the only bank which has given its official backing to Air One, while Monte dei Paschi has said it's looking into the deal. The other banks have declined to comment.   The Italian government, which may all or part of the state's 49.9% stake in Alitalia, said Friday the deadline for binding bids had been delayed for the second time, to July 23.     -By Luca Di Leo, Dow Jones Newswires; +39 06 6782543; luca.dileo@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 10:24 ET (14:24 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) Research Reports: How Analysts Size Up Companies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited By Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.     Apollo Group   -- APOL-NNM     Market Perform   -- Price 58.43 on July 2   by Barrington Research     Apollo Group reported the financial results of its fiscal third quarter, ended May 31. Enrollment, revenue and earnings were all above expectations [bringing shares] near an 18-month high. Revenue increased 12.2% to $733.4 million from $653.4 million last year, above our estimate of $705 million and the First Call consensus of $702.9 million. Net income was $131.4 million, or $0.75 per share, compared to net income of $131.5 million, or 75 cents per share, last year and topped our estimate of 70 cents per share and the First Call consensus estimate of 69 cents per share.   Degree enrollment for University of Phoenix and Axia College increased 12.2% . . . as of May 31. . . . We've made the following changes to our earnings model: We now expect fiscal 2007 full-year revenue at $2.699 billion (+9%), above our prior estimate of $2.661 billion (+7.4%), and diluted EPS of $2.35 (flat from a year ago), also above our prior estimate of $2.25 (-4.3%). . . . Apollo's stock is up 50% [year to date] and is trading at 20.6 times the consensus calendar 2008 earnings estimate. On an EV/Ebitda [enterprise value/earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization] basis, APOL has a multiple of 14 times versus the current peer group average of 16.4 times.     Constellation Brands   -- STZ-NYSE     Buy   -- Price 24.28 on July 2   by Bank of America     Raising target to 27 from 25, and 2008 [estimated earnings per share] to 1.39 from 1.35 [a share; Street consensus 1.38], and 09E EPS to 1.82 from 1.79 [Street: 1.68]. While the shares [of this international producer and marketer of wine, beer, and spirits] have not fully recovered from FY1Q07 collapse, we do believe the 28% rebound (versus 7.2% for the Standard & Poor's 500) off the bottom does begin to accommodate some level of earnings recovery in 2H08 and FY09. We continue to see upside potential to consensus estimates, as conservative guidance and overly negative extrapolation of one-off trends in U.S. wine are likely to fade over the next 12 months. Our valuation assumes 14.8 times our FY09E of $1.82, which is in line with the average multiple of 14.8 times over the last two years and 14 times over the last five years. Faster growth as earnings normalize could push the multiple modestly higher; however, the new [joint-venture] structure of the beer business should deflate the multiple relative to history.     Double-Take Software   -- DBTK-NNM     Outperform   -- Price 16.41 on July 2   by Pacific Crest     Public since December 2006, Double-Take Software is well-positioned in the Windows-replication market with its patented architecture and unique filtering technology with real-time, byte-level replication, and it should sustain 25% or better revenue growth for at least the next three years, in our view. Our 12-month price target of 20 is based on 27 times our 2008 EPS estimate of 75 cents. This is a reasonable multiple,  relative to Double-Take's revenue growth prospects and our forecast of profits doubling over the next two years. We are modeling a compound annual revenue growth rate of 27% over the next two years, which would equate to a PEG [price-to-earnings-growth] ratio of 1 times. Additionally, Double-Take has a strong balance sheet, with net cash in excess of $2 per share from the initial public offering proceeds. Market and macroeconomic conditions could interfere with the realization of this price target, as could risks such as competing against larger [rivals] with greater resources such as EMC, Symantec and Network Appliance; Windows exclusivity; dependence on top five partners that account for over 50% of its sales.     Kraft Foods   -- KFT-NYSE     Market Perform   -- Price 34.66 on July 3   by Wachovia     Kraft [will] acquire Danone's biscuits unit, rais[ing] international exposure. The wait is over -- CEO Irene Rosenfeld has announced her first major deal. The binding offer for Danone's global biscuits, for $7.2 billion (or 13.2 times FY07E Ebitda), immediately raises international and emerging-markets exposure, with numerous opportunities also likely available to cross-leverage the legacy portfolio -- eventual cost synergies pegged at 7% of sales and the deal is expected to be accretive during year one. As regulatory approval awaits, the deal will likely close by year end -- we're maintaining estimates and await updated core commentary from FQ2 EPS.   Our $33-to-$35 [target] range is based on 11 times our CY07E EV/Ebitda (roughly in line with peers). Risks include competition from private label in key categories and an emerging strategy favoring innovation and product mix.     Life Partners Holdings   -- LPHI-NNM     Speculative Buy   -- Price 36.21 on July 3   by Taglich Brothers     Life Partners Holdings is the parent of Life Partners, the oldest and one of the most active companies in the secondary market for life-settlement transactions -- which involve purchase of an existing life-insurance policy at a discount to its face value for investment purposes. . . . We're reiterating our Speculative Buy rating for shares of LPHI and increasing 12-month price target to 63 (previously 16). The big jump is based on a valuation on greatly increased earnings estimates . . . LPHI expects to report a 185% increase in [1Q] revenue, to $17.6 million from $6.2 million. Net income is expected to increase to $4.7 million or 49 cents per diluted share, versus net income of $200,000 or 5 cents per diluted share.   We believe the significant ramp-up in Life Partners' revenue over the last two quarters was due to market-share gains related to a lawsuit against a major competitor. In October 2006, the Attorney General for the State of New York filed a civil lawsuit against Coventry First, alleging Coventry made secret payments to life-settlement brokers. We believe market-share gains combined with continuing growth of the industry should result in LPHI's reporting significant top- and bottom-line growth.     Pharmion   -- PHRM-NNM     Sell   -- Price 29.45 on July 2   by Zacks Equity Research     Pharmion is a global pharmaceutical company focused on acquiring, developing, and commercializing products for treating hematology and oncology patients. The company has two main growth drivers, Thalidomide and Vidaza. Yet, sales of both are stalling [due to] fierce competition . . . Without acceleration in Vidaza prescriptions, [PHRM stock] will remain under pressure. Therefore, we maintain Sell rating, with a 23 target. . . . significantly ramping [research-and-development] and [sales, general and administrative] costs will cause Pharmion to post negative EPS the next two years. The company's positive EPS in 2005 was short-lived. Revenues will be flat until 2008 when new drivers will kick in. We believe Pharmion shares will be under pressure in next six to 12 months due to lackluster performance of Vidaza and Thalidomide. Other initiatives will not kick in until the end of 2007. . . . Vidaza was approved by the Food and Drug Administration in May 2004 for treatment of leukemia-predecessor, myelodysplastic syndrome. Another key product is Thalidomide for [treating] multiple myeloma and leprosy. . . . PHRM also acquired the rights to three pipeline candidates, Satraplatin, MGCD0103 and Amrubicin.     Transactions Systems Architects   -- TSAI-NNM     Buy   -- Price 33.66 on July 2   by Janney Montgomery Scott     The company [recently] released its first-quarter 10Q for the period ended Dec. 31, 2006; results were in line with preliminary guidance provided earlier this year. The filing avoided a July 2 hard Nasdaq delisting deadline and the company's March period 10Q (fiscal second quarter) remains outstanding, with a hard August 16 Nasdaq deadline. The filing delays are the consequence of a previously disclosed stock-option investigation. In early June, the company lowered its 2007 calendar-year guidance and offered positive commentary on new business wins during the March quarter . . . things are beginning to stabilize and the company remains well positioned to take advantage of ongoing secular trends . . . We are increasing our 12-month fair-value estimate to 40 a share.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/9) The New Face Of Janus
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lawrence C. Strauss   Imagine a mutual-fund firm that invests in stock research, likes to take a contrarian view, pays attention to a company's cash flows and is willing to hang tough with stocks about which it has strong convictions.   American Funds? Dodge & Cox? T. Rowe Price?   All of the above. But what about Janus Capital Group?   A few years ago, linking Janus (ticker: JNS) with these others would have been laughable. Back in the tech bubble and dot-com eras, it was a pure growth and momentum shop, often making huge bets on one stock and willing to jump in and out of positions at the first whiff of good or bad news. When the Nasdaq-traded shares began crumbling in 2000, Janus did, too, as investors fled its suddenly money-losing mutual funds. Janus' assets, which peaked at $330 billion in March 2000, got as low as $130 billion in September 2004.   But now the Denver fund giant is back, with a different investment philosophy, new leaders and, most important, sharpened performance. Whether it fares well enough over the long term to rank with the T. Rowes of the world remains to be seen. But investors seem to believe that it's at least headed in the right direction. They've bid up its shares to around 30 -- almost double their 52-week low. But part of that gain has been fueled by speculation that, if Janus falters, it will be taken over or bought out.   Undeniably, Janus has been producing some good news for shareholders in a number of its funds. As of May 31, 69% of the assets it managed were in funds with four- or five-star Morningstar ratings based on five-year returns, according to Goldman Sachs. That's well ahead of the 48% average for all publicly traded asset managers tracked by Goldman. Janus' funds also are above average when judged on one- and three-year results.   Janus, named for the two-headed Roman god of beginnings and endings, has adopted a more disciplined approach to growth-stock investing. Its new face is shown in the improved, but still not great, performance of its flagships -- Janus (JANSX) and Janus Worldwide (JAWWX) and the good longer-term returns of Janus Contrarian (JSVAX) and other funds.   Making this more impressive is that it's occurring during what has been a protracted, frustrating stretch for growth investing --  recent signs of a rotation away from value stocks notwithstanding -- and with memories of Janus' post-bubble-era miseries still alive in investors' minds and wallets. "If you lose money for people, they don't forget that very quickly," says Marc Irizarry, who covers Janus for Goldman Sachs.   The saving grace, according to Kevin P. Quirk, a partner at Casey, Quirk & Associates, an asset-management consultancy in Darien, Conn.: "Janus has learned a lot since [the tech implosion]. They've forged a different way of investing." That includes paying more attention to risk control, by avoiding overlapping positions, broadening the universe of securities its analysts look at and spending more time on whether a stock has enough downside protection.   Although the tide appears to be turning, Janus is still struggling to attract new cash. At the end of March, it was overseeing $176.2 billion in assets -- little more than half of its total at its 2000 peak.   In the first quarter, flows were flat, excluding those for the company's successful quantitative Intech products. The situation varies by fund. For example, Janus Contrarian is attracting money, but Janus Worldwide is still bleeding bucks.   Lousy past performance isn't the only impediment to better cash inflows. In August 2004, Janus settled a market-timing case with state and federal regulators. Certain investors had been allowed to move in and out of its funds quickly, contrary to the stated policy, in exchange for parking money in other funds. Market timing lets short-term investors pocket profits at the expense of longer-term shareholders.   The market-timing mess damaged the firm's credibility, already hurt by its funds' post-bubble swoon. "I was quite ashamed to see an organization go through that and lose the trust of our fund holders," says Janus veteran David Decker, who runs the Contrarian fund.   In an e-mail, financial planner Harold Evensky of Coral Gables, Fla., asserts that "Janus still has a ways to go before it's seriously on the independent-adviser screen," owing to the "credibility gap engendered by its past behavior."   Acknowledges Janus CEO Gary Black: "We still need to regain the confidence of people we didn't do a good job for."   Black joined Janus as president and chief investment officer in 2004, as part of a new management team led by former Charles Schwab executive Steve Scheid.   Black, who became chief executive early last year when Scheid retired, gets good reviews from people in the industry. He has a strong investment background, having worked as a research analyst at Sanford Bernstein and later serving as chief investment officer for Goldman Sachs Asset Management's global equities division. This pedigree has helped him command respect at an organization known for having very strong-willed portfolio managers accustomed to wielding a lot of internal clout. He's quick to credit his funds' improved performance to their portfolio managers and to Jim Goff, Janus' director of research.   Founded in 1969 by Tom Bailey, Janus was a small shop for many years. When Goff joined the firm in 1988, he was one of only two analysts, both generalists.   Fueled by strong performance by funds like Janus, Janus Twenty (JAVLX) and Janus Worldwide, the Denver asset manager grew at an extraordinary clip in the 1990s. Its high-profile managers, including Tom Marsico, Helen Young Hayes (both now long departed) and Scott Schoelzel, became stars. The growth was especially strong in the late '90s, as big-cap tech and telecom stocks like Dell (DELL) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) surged.   "The Janus mystique took on a life of its own," recalls co-chief investment officer Jonathan Coleman, who joined the company in 1994 as an analyst. "It was a good company, but it wasn't prepared to handle that amount of inflows."   For one thing, too many of its portfolio managers had the same securities. In early 1999, the firm's top 25 stock-fund holdings accounted for nearly 55% of all of its equity assets. That's down to about 30% today.   Another big hole: The research department lacked depth, specialization and experience. When tech started to sink, "we had no ideas on the shelf to turn to," says Goff, who became research chief in early 2002. "That left us very slow afoot." Goff now leads more than 30 stock analysts and 20 stock research associates. Eight years ago, the figures were 22 and zero.   In 2000, the Janus equity research team covered about 500 companies, 100 of them foreign. Today, it follows about 1,400, including 570 outside the U.S. And Janus has hired more seasoned analysts, many of them specialists. Areas of coverage these days include retailing, energy, financials, industrials and consumer staples. "You didn't think of Janus when you thought of those areas," says Goff.   The investment culture also has become more disciplined. "Valuation has become a far more important part of what they do," says John F. Casey, chairman of Casey, Quirk & Associates.   Janus Contrarian manager Decker, sums up his investment philosophy this way: "You are more likely to find situations that are undervalued, relative to their intrinsic value, if the company is out of favor and misunderstood. We start with that premise."   Decker says that he and other managers, such as Jason Yee of Janus Worldwide and David Corkins of Janus Fund, "look for high-quality businesses that generate strong cash flow and strong returns on capital. Then the question is: What are you willing to pay for those streams of cash flows?"   Decker, who has run the fund since 2000, appears to be paying the right prices. His fund, which has about $7.4 billion in assets, around 40% of it in foreign stocks, ranks at the very top of its Lipper and Morningstar peer groups, based on one-, three- and five-year returns. Its five-year annual return of 22.6% bests the S&P 500's by more than 11 percentage points. Among the stocks Decker has made money on are Tyco International (TYC), which he still holds, and Sallie Mae, or SLM (SLM), which he has sold.   CEO Black has emphasized three- and five-year returns in determining compensation for his fund managers, who are said to be among the highest-paid in the business.   He's also put more focus on risk control. One result: Standard deviations -- which measure the variability of returns -- are lower. From May 1998 to May 2001, for example, Janus Twenty had an annual standard deviation of 32.52, versus 18.72 for the S&P 500, according to Lipper. But in the three years ended May 31, the standard deviation was 10.42, versus 7.15 for the benchmark. Simply put, many Janus funds have outpaced their peers while taking on less risk than they did in the 1990s, when the company didn't even have a risk-management committee, as many investment organizations do. Says Rachel Barnard, a Morningstar analyst who follows the company: "That's made for less flashy returns, but they are more consistent."   Yee, who took over Janus Worldwide in 2004, worked at the firm in the mid-1990s before leaving for another company and then returning in 2000. "People are making use of a wider set of tools to gauge valuation and risk," he says. One is discounted-cash-flow analysis, in which a company's future cash flows are estimated and then measured in today's dollars, using an appropriate discount rate.   The risk panel's aim isn't to prevent managers from taking risks -- after all, that's how they make money for clients. Instead, it tries to ensure that the chances taken are reasonable, intended and commensurate with the potential reward.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  July 07, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
